List Words works with relatively small texts of under a megabyte in size. It is part of the TAPoRware collection of tools; there are XML and plain text versions available as well.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThis tool’s functionality has been incorporated into Voyant available online at www.voyant-tools.org.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/1.jpg","creators_name":"Geoffrey Rockwell et. al.","creators_email":"grockwel@ualberta.ca","creators_url":"http://geoffreyrockwell.com/","star_average":4.0,"url":"","last_updated":"2020-10-08","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/1-thumb.jpg","rating_count":1,"recipes":""}
detail: This tool lists words in an HTML document, either uploaded by the user or from a web address. List Words works with relatively small texts of under a megabyte in size. It is part of the TAPoRware collection of tools; there are XML and plain text versions available as well.This tool’s functionality has been incorporated into Voyant available online at www.voyant-tools.org.
name: List Words - HTML (TAPoRware)

data_tapor: {"id":4,"user_id":1,"name":"Wordle","detail":"\u003cp\u003eWordle is an online toy for generating \u003ca href=\"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Word_cloud\"\u003eword clouds\u003c/a\u003e using the text you provide.  Text can be submitted by providing an URL or by pasting raw text into an input.  The most frequent words from the text are then used as the source for the resulting visualization, where frequency is used to determine the size of each word.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eYou may customize the output by choosing from a variety of display options (layout, font, colours) or use the randomize feature to get a random visualization.  Additionally, there is built-in stop word support for many common languages, and the option to change the word case.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/4.jpg","creators_name":"Jonathan Feinberg","creators_email":"jdf@pobox.com","creators_url":"http://mrfeinberg.com/","star_average":4.0,"url":"http://www.wordle.net/","last_updated":"2018-10-17","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/4-thumb.jpg","rating_count":2,"recipes":""}
detail: Wordle is an online toy for generating word clouds using the text you provide.  Text can be submitted by providing an URL or by pasting raw text into an input.  The most frequent words from the text are then used as the source for the resulting visualization, where frequency is used to determine the size of each word. You may customize the output by choosing from a variety of display options (layout, font, colours) or use the randomize feature to get a random visualization.  Additionally, there is built-in stop word support for many common languages, and the option to change the word case.
name: Wordle

data_tapor: {"id":5,"user_id":null,"name":"OrlandoVision (OVis)","detail":"\u003cp\u003eAn application for visualizing a specific collection of authors, and the links or associations between them.  Links are determined by co-occurrence in the Orlando dataset.  The current dataset consists of authors, other people associated with them, and the text entries upon which these associations are based.  The application is designed in such a way that it could be extended to use other datasets as well.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003eThe display can be customized in the several ways.  Node colours, shapes and sizes can be altered.  More significantly, the layout of the graph can be chosen from amongst several different algorithms.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003eAs the collection is quite large, there are many filtering options available.  In terms of author, the following categories can be specified: gender, author/non-author, and author nationality.  The user can create complex search queries of the authors and the text, and specify a date restriction for the authors' life span.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003eEach association in the text has been tagged with one or more semantic attributes, i.e. the type or meaning of the relation between the people.  These tags have been organized into a tree, moving from general to more specific relations.  Each tag in the tree can be checked/unchecked, further filtering the results.\u003cbr\u003e\u003cbr\u003eFinally, a data set and customizations can be saved as a session which can then be loaded at a later time.  In addition, screenshots of the current layout can be saved to an image file.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/5.jpg","creators_name":"The Orlando Project","creators_email":"orlando@ualberta.ca","creators_url":"http://www.ualberta.ca/orlando","star_average":2.0,"url":"http://www.artsrn.ualberta.ca/orlando/","last_updated":"2018-11-01","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/5-thumb.jpg","rating_count":1,"recipes":""}
detail: An application for visualizing a specific collection of authors, and the links or associations between them.  Links are determined by co-occurrence in the Orlando dataset.  The current dataset consists of authors, other people associated with them, and the text entries upon which these associations are based.  The application is designed in such a way that it could be extended to use other datasets as well.The display can be customized in the several ways.  Node colours, shapes and sizes can be altered.  More significantly, the layout of the graph can be chosen from amongst several different algorithms.As the collection is quite large, there are many filtering options available.  In terms of author, the following categories can be specified: gender, author/non-author, and author nationality.  The user can create complex search queries of the authors and the text, and specify a date restriction for the authors' life span.Each association in the text has been tagged with one or more semantic attributes, i.e. the type or meaning of the relation between the people.  These tags have been organized into a tree, moving from general to more specific relations.  Each tag in the tree can be checked/unchecked, further filtering the results.Finally, a data set and customizations can be saved as a session which can then be loaded at a later time.  In addition, screenshots of the current layout can be saved to an image file.
name: OrlandoVision (OVis)

data_tapor: {"id":10,"user_id":null,"name":"Voyant Bubblelines","detail":"\u003cp\u003eBubblelines is a visualization tool that helps to understand patterns of word repetition in one or more documents. detail: Bubblelines is a visualization tool that helps to understand patterns of word repetition in one or more documents. Each document is represented as a horizontal line and each seach term is represented as a bubble – the bubble represents the frequency of the term in the corresponding segment of text (the text is divided into segments of equal length).
name: Voyant Bubblelines

data_tapor: {"id":11,"user_id":null,"name":"Voyant Bubbles","detail":"\u003cp\u003eBubbles reads the words in a document (or corpus) and displays the highest frequency words within proportionately large bubbles. Once you arrive to Bubbles, insert / upload your content and let the tool perform its analysis.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/11.jpg","creators_name":"Stéfan Sinclair and Geoffrey Rockwell","creators_email":"sgs@mcmaster.ca","creators_url":"http://stefansinclair.name/","star_average":5.0,"url":"http://voyant-tools.org/tool/Bubbles/","last_updated":"2018-10-05","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/11-thumb.jpg","rating_count":1,"recipes":""}
detail: Bubbles reads the words in a document (or corpus) and displays the highest frequency words within proportionately large bubbles. Once you arrive to Bubbles, insert / upload your content and let the tool perform its analysis.
name: Voyant Bubbles

data_tapor: {"id":24,"user_id":null,"name":"Orlando Degrees of Separation","detail":"\u003cp\u003eOrlando contains a relatively large corpus, currently consisting of details about the life and writing careers of roughly 1000 British women writers, amounting to 6.8 million words with 2.2 million semantic tags for everything from paragraphs to politics, plots, or relations with publishers.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/24.jpg","creators_name":"The Orlando Project was led by Patricia Clements, Isobel Grundy, and Susan Brown at the University of Alberta and the University of Guelph. detail: Orlando contains a relatively large corpus, currently consisting of details about the life and writing careers of roughly 1000 British women writers, amounting to 6.8 million words with 2.2 million semantic tags for everything from paragraphs to politics, plots, or relations with publishers.
name: Orlando Degrees of Separation

data_tapor: {"id":26,"user_id":null,"name":"Voyant Flowerbed (beta)","detail":"\u003cp class=\"western\"\u003eFlowerbed is a simple visualization tool for viewing up to two documents. Each document is presented as a “flowerbed”, wherein each word is a flower. The height of the flower is determined by the relative frequency of that word within the document. The petals on each flower represent features associated with the word. When two documents are present in chosen the corpus, the second is mirrored below the first. In this way it is possible to do a cursory comparison of the documents.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/26.jpg","creators_name":"Stéfan Sinclair","creators_email":"","creators_url":"http://stefansinclair.name/","star_average":0.0,"url":"","last_updated":"2018-09-28","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/26-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: Flowerbed is a simple visualization tool for viewing up to two documents. Each document is presented as a “flowerbed”, wherein each word is a flower. The height of the flower is determined by the relative frequency of that word within the document. The petals on each flower represent features associated with the word. When two documents are present in chosen the corpus, the second is mirrored below the first. In this way it is possible to do a cursory comparison of the documents.
name: Voyant Flowerbed (beta)

data_tapor: {"id":27,"user_id":null,"name":"Voyant FeatureClusters (beta)","detail":"\u003cp class=\"western\"\u003eFeatureClusters is a visualization tool for viewing associations between words, based on commonalities in the feature sets of the words. This is illustrated using a force-directed graph, wherein each word is a node in the graph. Nodes are connected to one another if they share the same feature. Features are represented by the smaller circles (or petals) which surround each word. Moving your mouse over a word will show the feature details associated with that word. Clicking on a word will highlight its connections to other words.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/27.jpg","creators_name":"Stéfan Sinclair","creators_email":"","creators_url":"http://stefansinclair.name/","star_average":3.0,"url":"","last_updated":"2018-10-03","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/27-thumb.jpg","rating_count":1,"recipes":""}
detail: FeatureClusters is a visualization tool for viewing associations between words, based on commonalities in the feature sets of the words. This is illustrated using a force-directed graph, wherein each word is a node in the graph. Nodes are connected to one another if they share the same feature. Features are represented by the smaller circles (or petals) which surround each word. Moving your mouse over a word will show the feature details associated with that word. Clicking on a word will highlight its connections to other words.
name: Voyant FeatureClusters (beta)

data_tapor: {"id":28,"user_id":null,"name":"Voyant Translate Skin (beta)","detail":"\u003cp class=\"western\"\u003eThe translate skin is\u003cimg src=\"../../system/icons/28/original/translateskin.png\" alt=\"\"\u003e a custom skin for Voyeur Tools which offers multiple translations of the same document. Target languages for the translations are chosen from a comprehensive list and the Google Translate API is used to provide the resulting texts. These are used to populate the final view which consists of a series of Cirrus tools, one for each translation.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp class=\"western\"\u003eFurther translations can be produced for any of the texts by selecting one from the “Next Translation” drop-down. The Cirrus tools can be arranged in two layouts: tile, and circular. detail: The translate skin is a custom skin for Voyeur Tools which offers multiple translations of the same document. Target languages for the translations are chosen from a comprehensive list and the Google Translate API is used to provide the resulting texts. These are used to populate the final view which consists of a series of Cirrus tools, one for each translation. Further translations can be produced for any of the texts by selecting one from the “Next Translation” drop-down. The Cirrus tools can be arranged in two layouts: tile, and circular. They can also be re-sized and moved to produce a custom layout.
name: Voyant Translate Skin (beta)

data_tapor: {"id":41,"user_id":null,"name":"Collocation - HTML (TAPoRware)","detail":"\u003cp\u003eThis tool provides all words directly before and after a user-specified word, based on the desired context of words, lines, sentences or paragraphs. The results can be sorted alphabetically, by frequency, or by Z-score (an indication of how far and in what direction that item deviates from its distribution's mean, expressed in units of its distribution's standard deviation). XML and plain text versions are also available within the TAPoRware toolsets.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThis tool’s functionality has been incorporated into Voyant available online at www.voyant-tools.org.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/41.jpg","creators_name":"Geoffrey Rockwell et. al.","creators_email":"grockwel@ualberta.ca","creators_url":"http://geoffreyrockwell.com/","star_average":0.0,"url":"","last_updated":"2020-10-08","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/41-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}

name: Speech Tagger - Plain Text (TAPoRware)

data_tapor: {"id":66,"user_id":null,"name":"Aggregator - Other (TAPoRware)","detail":"\u003cp\u003eThis tool aggregates texts/subtexts from different locations into a single text. The original texts can be from a user-specified web page or files located on one's computer. Aggregating subtexts requires all documents to share a common subtext tag, such as the \u003cspan class=\"code\"\u003e\u0026lt;body\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e tag. The aggregator tool will grab the contents from the texts to form a single new text.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/66.jpg","creators_name":"Geoffrey Rockwell et. al.","creators_email":"grockwel@ualberta.ca","creators_url":"http://geoffreyrockwell.com/","star_average":1.0,"url":"","last_updated":"2020-10-08","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/66-thumb.jpg","rating_count":1,"recipes":""}
detail: This tool aggregates texts/subtexts from different locations into a single text. The original texts can be from a user-specified web page or files located on one's computer. Aggregating subtexts requires all documents to share a common subtext tag, such as the <body> tag. The aggregator tool will grab the contents from the texts to form a single new text.
name: Aggregator - Other (TAPoRware)

data_tapor: {"id":68,"user_id":null,"name":"Raining Words - Other (TAPoR)","detail":"\u003cp\u003e'Raining Words' is a tool designed to display word frequency information, minus the words in a chosen stop list, from a user-specified document in a Java applet. High frequency words appear larger and move more slowly than lower frequency words. This tool requires Java 1.4.2_08 or a more recent version for your browser.  As the TAPoRware interface defaults to opening the applet in a new window, popups must also be enabled from the TAPoRware site in order to see the results.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThis tool’s functionality has been incorporated into Voyant available online at www.voyant-tools.org.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/68.jpg","creators_name":"Geoffrey Rockwell et. al.","creators_email":"grockwel@ualberta.ca","creators_url":"http://geoffreyrockwell.com/","star_average":0.0,"url":"","last_updated":"2020-10-08","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/68-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: 'Raining Words' is a tool designed to display word frequency information, minus the words in a chosen stop list, from a user-specified document in a Java applet. High frequency words appear larger and move more slowly than lower frequency words. This tool requires Java 1.4.2_08 or a more recent version for your browser.  As the TAPoRware interface defaults to opening the applet in a new window, popups must also be enabled from the TAPoRware site in order to see the results.This tool’s functionality has been incorporated into Voyant available online at www.voyant-tools.org.
name: Raining Words - Other (TAPoR)

data_tapor: {"id":69,"user_id":null,"name":"Raw Grep - Other (TAPoRware)","detail":"\u003cp\u003eThis tool can find a user-specified string of characters anywhere in a text document. If the string is part of a word or another non-space string, the word or the non-space string will be displayed as a unit. The search can also be used to view a concordance of either words, sentences, or lines surrounding the result. The tool will treat HTML or XML text as plain text.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThis tool’s functionality has been incorporated into Voyant available online at www.voyant-tools.org.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/69.jpg","creators_name":"Geoffrey Rockwell et. al.","creators_email":"grockwel@ualberta.ca","creators_url":"http://geoffreyrockwell.com/","star_average":0.0,"url":"","last_updated":"2020-10-08","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/69-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: This tool can find a user-specified string of characters anywhere in a text document. If the string is part of a word or another non-space string, the word or the non-space string will be displayed as a unit. The search can also be used to view a concordance of either words, sentences, or lines surrounding the result. The tool will treat HTML or XML text as plain text.This tool’s functionality has been incorporated into Voyant available online at www.voyant-tools.org.
name: Raw Grep - Other (TAPoRware)

data_tapor: {"id":72,"user_id":null,"name":"Weighted Centroid - Other (TAPoRware)","detail":"\u003cp\u003eThe Weighted Centroid is a java applet designed to display a circular graph based on word distribution data. The text is divided up into an arbitrary number of units, which are positioned around the circumference of the circle in a clockwise sequence. The more times a word appears in a particular text unit, the closer the word will be to that unit in the circle, and the more units it appears in, the closer it will appera to the centre.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/72.jpg","creators_name":"Geoffrey Rockwell et. al.","creators_email":"grockwel@ualberta.ca","creators_url":"http://geoffreyrockwell.com/","star_average":0.0,"url":"","last_updated":"2020-10-08","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/72-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: The Weighted Centroid is a java applet designed to display a circular graph based on word distribution data. The text is divided up into an arbitrary number of units, which are positioned around the circumference of the circle in a clockwise sequence. The more times a word appears in a particular text unit, the closer the word will be to that unit in the circle, and the more units it appears in, the closer it will appera to the centre.
name: Weighted Centroid - Other (TAPoRware)

data_tapor: {"id":73,"user_id":null,"name":"List Word Pairs - Beta (TAPoRware)","detail":"\u003cp\u003eThis tool lists all word pairs found in a document alphabetically, by frequency, by order of appearance, or in reversed alphabetical order. Users may specify restrictions to narrow the results. This tool is currently only available for plain text documents. data_tapor: {"id":75,"user_id":null,"name":"Word Cloud - Beta (TAPoRware)","detail":"\u003cp\u003eThis tool generates a word cloud of the top frequency words from a text document, with word size determined by its frequency. The user can specify how many words are to be included from the document, whether to apply a modified Glasgow Stop Words list, and the order in which the words are displayed. Clicking on a word in the resultant word cloud will generate a concordance for that word. This tool is currently only available for plain text documents. Should the user provide an HTML or XML text, all tags will be stripped and it will be processed as plain text.\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003eThis tool’s functionality has been incorporated into Voyant available online at www.voyant-tools.org.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/75.jpg","creators_name":"Geoffrey Rockwell et. al.","creators_email":"grockwel@ualberta.ca","creators_url":"http://geoffreyrockwell.com/","star_average":1.0,"url":"","last_updated":"2020-10-08","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/75-thumb.jpg","rating_count":1,"recipes":""}
detail: This tool generates a word cloud of the top frequency words from a text document, with word size determined by its frequency. The user can specify how many words are to be included from the document, whether to apply a modified Glasgow Stop Words list, and the order in which the words are displayed. Clicking on a word in the resultant word cloud will generate a concordance for that word. This tool is currently only available for plain text documents. Should the user provide an HTML or XML text, all tags will be stripped and it will be processed as plain text.This tool’s functionality has been incorporated into Voyant available online at www.voyant-tools.org.
name: Word Cloud - Beta (TAPoRware)

data_tapor: {"id":82,"user_id":null,"name":"Keywords Finder - Beta (TAPoRware)","detail":"\u003cp\u003eThis tool identifies keywords or key phrases within a user-specified text, using the assumption that they will appear with the greatest frequency. It applies a stemmer to every word. Plain text input is recommended. All tags will be stripped from an HTML or XML file submitted, and the resulting document will be processed as if it were plain text.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003ePlease note: This tool takes a few minutes to process a given document.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eThis tool’s functionality has been incorporated into Voyant available online at www.voyant-tools.org.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/82.jpg","creators_name":"Geoffrey Rockwell et. al.","creators_email":"grockwel@ualberta.ca","creators_url":"http://geoffreyrockwell.com/","star_average":0.0,"url":"","last_updated":"2020-10-08","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/82-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: This tool identifies keywords or key phrases within a user-specified text, using the assumption that they will appear with the greatest frequency. It applies a stemmer to every word. Plain text input is recommended. All tags will be stripped from an HTML or XML file submitted, and the resulting document will be processed as if it were plain text. Please note: This tool takes a few minutes to process a given document. This tool’s functionality has been incorporated into Voyant available online at www.voyant-tools.org.
name: Keywords Finder - Beta (TAPoRware)

data_tapor: {"id":85,"user_id":null,"name":"CHNM: Scribe","detail":"\u003cp\u003eScribe, now in version 3.5, is a free note-taking program available for both PC and Mac. Aimed particularly at historians, this program allows researchers to create digital note cards for managing sources, research notes, contacts, images, glossaries, outlines, timelines and more. Furthermore, it enables organization, keyword indexing, searching, linking and cross-referencing of all entries. Entries can be entered directly or imported from online catalogues such as Amazon.com. Information entered in Scribe can be exported directly to Zotero in addition to assembling, printing or copying formatted bibliographies directly from the program. Articles can be stored directly within the program, enabling researchers to search out and highlight particular words within the text in addition to the relevant researcher notes.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/85.jpg","creators_name":"Elena Razlogova","creators_email":"erazlogo@alcor.concordia.ca","creators_url":"http://elenarazlogova.org/","star_average":0.0,"url":"http://chnm.gmu.edu/tools/scribe/","last_updated":"2018-10-17","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/85-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: Scribe, now in version 3.5, is a free note-taking program available for both PC and Mac. Aimed particularly at historians, this program allows researchers to create digital note cards for managing sources, research notes, contacts, images, glossaries, outlines, timelines and more. Furthermore, it enables organization, keyword indexing, searching, linking and cross-referencing of all entries. Entries can be entered directly or imported from online catalogues such as Amazon.com. Information entered in Scribe can be exported directly to Zotero in addition to assembling, printing or copying formatted bibliographies directly from the program. Articles can be stored directly within the program, enabling researchers to search out and highlight particular words within the text in addition to the relevant researcher notes.
name: CHNM: Scribe

data_tapor: {"id":86,"user_id":1,"name":"Anthologize","detail":"\u003cp\u003eAnthologize is a free, open-source plugin for WordPress 3.0. It enables WordPress to be used as a platform for publishing electronic texts in PDF, ePUB or TEI format. The plugin enables users to grab their existing blog posts, export content from external feeds or compose new content directly in Anthologize, then apply outlining, create a custom order, and edit content into a single document for export. Anthologize requires a self-hosted or local installation of WordPress.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/86.jpg","creators_name":"One Week, One Tool","creators_email":"info@anthologize.org","creators_url":"http://anthologize.org/about/oneweek/","star_average":0.0,"url":"http://anthologize.org/","last_updated":"2018-10-12","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/86-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: Anthologize is a free, open-source plugin for WordPress 3.0. It enables WordPress to be used as a platform for publishing electronic texts in PDF, ePUB or TEI format. The plugin enables users to grab their existing blog posts, export content from external feeds or compose new content directly in Anthologize, then apply outlining, create a custom order, and edit content into a single document for export. Anthologize requires a self-hosted or local installation of WordPress.
name: Anthologize

data_tapor: {"id":87,"user_id":null,"name":"Flamenco Search","detail":"\u003cp\u003eFlamenco Search is a downloadable web-based interface from the UC Berkley School of Information based in Python, designed to run on a server. It streamlines the browsing of large collections. It is particularly valuable for items such as documents or images, enabling website visitors to explore content via a hierarchy of categories and subcategories called facets. Users can assign keywords and metadata which is then used to guide site visitors to the choices that best meet their interests, while allowing them to refine or expand their query and remain oriented in relation to the rest of the collection.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/87.jpg","creators_name":"Marti A. Hearst","creators_email":"hearst@ischool.berkeley.edu ","creators_url":"http://people.ischool.berkeley.edu/~hearst/","star_average":0.0,"url":"http://flamenco.berkeley.edu/index.html","last_updated":"2014-12-31","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/87-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: Flamenco Search is a downloadable web-based interface from the UC Berkley School of Information based in Python, designed to run on a server. It streamlines the browsing of large collections. It is particularly valuable for items such as documents or images, enabling website visitors to explore content via a hierarchy of categories and subcategories called facets. Users can assign keywords and metadata which is then used to guide site visitors to the choices that best meet their interests, while allowing them to refine or expand their query and remain oriented in relation to the rest of the collection.
name: Flamenco Search

data_tapor: {"id":88,"user_id":null,"name":"Commentpress","detail":"\u003cp\u003eCommentpress is an open source theme and plugin for Wordpress 3.3.1 or later designed to enable readers to contribute comments to each paragraph of a text and display those comments in the margins. Commentpress turns a text into a conversation, whether a blog or a fixed document such as an essay, book or article. It may also be used to add a gloss or annotations to a document. This tool is also available for BuddyPress and BP Group Blog.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/88.jpg","creators_name":"Eddie Tejeda","creators_email":"","creators_url":"http://www.visudo.com/","star_average":0.0,"url":"http://www.futureofthebook.org/commentpress/","last_updated":"2018-10-05","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/88-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: Commentpress is an open source theme and plugin for Wordpress 3.3.1 or later designed to enable readers to contribute comments to each paragraph of a text and display those comments in the margins. Commentpress turns a text into a conversation, whether a blog or a fixed document such as an essay, book or article. It may also be used to add a gloss or annotations to a document. This tool is also available for BuddyPress and BP Group Blog.
name: Commentpress

data_tapor: {"id":89,"user_id":null,"name":"TILE (Text Image Linking Environment)","detail":"\u003cp\u003eThe Text-Image Linking Environment (TILE) is a web-based tool that enables users to select regions of an image and link them to text. TILE is a system for creating and editing image-based electronic editions and connecting them to digital archives of the texts. It has been designed for easy modification by integrating a plugin infrastructure.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/89.jpg","creators_name":"Maryland Institute for Technology in the Humanities","creators_email":"contact.tile@gmail.com","creators_url":"http://mith.umd.edu/","star_average":0.0,"url":"http://mith.umd.edu/tile/","last_updated":"2018-10-12","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/89-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: The Text-Image Linking Environment (TILE) is a web-based tool that enables users to select regions of an image and link them to text. TILE is a system for creating and editing image-based electronic editions and connecting them to digital archives of the texts. It has been designed for easy modification by integrating a plugin infrastructure.
name: TILE (Text Image Linking Environment)

data_tapor: {"id":90,"user_id":null,"name":"MONK (Metadata Offer New Knowledge)","detail":"\u003cp\u003eMONK (Metadata Offer New Knowledge) is a digital environment for humanities scholars. It is desgined to assist with the discovery and analysis of patterns within texts, incorporating full text content from corpora such as ECCO, EEBO and Early American Fiction directly into the tool. The MONK Workbench is the primary environment, permitting users to create worksets, perform analytics and save their results. In addition, the MONK workbench can be used in conjunction with the Flameco faceted browser and Zotero.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/90.jpg","creators_name":"MONK Project","creators_email":"monkproject@lis.illinois.edu","creators_url":"http://www.monkproject.org/","star_average":0.0,"url":"http://quest.library.illinois.edu/monk/project/downloads/","last_updated":"2018-10-19","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/90-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: MONK (Metadata Offer New Knowledge) is a digital environment for humanities scholars. It is desgined to assist with the discovery and analysis of patterns within texts, incorporating full text content from corpora such as ECCO, EEBO and Early American Fiction directly into the tool. The MONK Workbench is the primary environment, permitting users to create worksets, perform analytics and save their results. In addition, the MONK workbench can be used in conjunction with the Flameco faceted browser and Zotero.
name: MONK (Metadata Offer New Knowledge)

data_tapor: {"id":91,"user_id":1,"name":"MorphAdorner","detail":"\u003cp\u003eMorphAdorner, now in version 2.0, is a Java command-line program for the adornment of words in a text. At present, available adornments include standard spellings, parts of speech and lemmata, in addition to tokenization, the recognition of sentence boundaries and extracting names and places. Version 2.0 features a separate MorphAdorner Server, an improved integration with MONK's Abbot and improved processing of the Early English Books Online (EEBO), Eighteenth Century Collections Online (ECCO) and Evans Early American Imprint Collection corpori.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/91.jpg","creators_name":"Philip R. \"Pib\" Burns","creators_email":"pib@northwestern.edu","creators_url":"https://depot.northwestern.edu/~pib/","star_average":0.0,"url":"http://morphadorner.northwestern.edu/morphadorner/","last_updated":"2018-10-05","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/91-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: MorphAdorner, now in version 2.0, is a Java command-line program for the adornment of words in a text. At present, available adornments include standard spellings, parts of speech and lemmata, in addition to tokenization, the recognition of sentence boundaries and extracting names and places. Version 2.0 features a separate MorphAdorner Server, an improved integration with MONK's Abbot and improved processing of the Early English Books Online (EEBO), Eighteenth Century Collections Online (ECCO) and Evans Early American Imprint Collection corpori.
name: MorphAdorner

data_tapor: {"id":92,"user_id":null,"name":"NLTK 3.3 (Natural Language Toolkit)","detail":"\u003cp\u003eNLTK 2.0 (Natural Language Tooklt) is a free, open source collection of Python modules, linguistic data and documentation for research and development in natural language processing and text analytics, with distributions for Windows, Mac OS X and Linux. It offers a platform for building Python programs to work with human language data, and integrates a guide to programming fundamentals.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/92.jpg","creators_name":"NLTK Project","creators_email":"","creators_url":"http://nltk.org/","star_average":5.0,"url":"http://www.nltk.org/","last_updated":"2018-09-19","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/92-thumb.jpg","rating_count":2,"recipes":""}
detail: NLTK 2.0 (Natural Language Tooklt) is a free, open source collection of Python modules, linguistic data and documentation for research and development in natural language processing and text analytics, with distributions for Windows, Mac OS X and Linux. It offers a platform for building Python programs to work with human language data, and integrates a guide to programming fundamentals.
name: NLTK 3.3 (Natural Language Toolkit)

data_tapor: {"id":93,"user_id":null,"name":"WordHoard","detail":"\u003cp\u003eWordHoard is a tool for the study of large texts or transcribed speech. It annotates or tags texts by applying morphological, lexical, prosodic, and narratological criteria. Users may apply WordHoard to their own texts, or to the corpora included with the tool. At present, that corpora includes the entire canon of Early Greek epic (original and in translation), Chaucer, Shakespeare and Spencer.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/93.jpg","creators_name":"WordHoard Team","creators_email":"martinmueller@northwestern.edu","creators_url":"http://wordhoard.northwestern.edu/userman/index.html","star_average":0.0,"url":"http://wordhoard.northwestern.edu/userman/index.html","last_updated":"2018-10-05","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/93-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: WordHoard is a tool for the study of large texts or transcribed speech. It annotates or tags texts by applying morphological, lexical, prosodic, and narratological criteria. Users may apply WordHoard to their own texts, or to the corpora included with the tool. At present, that corpora includes the entire canon of Early Greek epic (original and in translation), Chaucer, Shakespeare and Spencer.
name: WordHoard

detail: PhiloGL is an open source WebGL Framework for advanced data visualization, creative coding and game development. It includes a module system encompassing Program and Shader management, IO, XHR, JSONP, Web Worker management, Effects and Tweening, among others.

data_tapor: {"id":95,"user_id":null,"name":"RiTa","detail":"\u003cp\u003eRiTa is a free, open-source natural language library for work with generative literature, offered as both a 'core' package of jar files and documentation, and a text-to-speech package. detail: Citeline was a tool for publishing bibliographies and citation collections on the web. It takes a BibTex file exported from Endnotes, Refworks and similar tools and turns the collection into an interactive, shareable exhibit. Citeline citation collections may also be exported in a variety of formats, such as BibTex, JSON, XML or tab-separated values. The Citeline project has been retired, and the website is no longer available. Information about Citeline is currently only available via the Internet Archive.
name: Citéline

detail: Gadget, a part of the SIMILE Widgets family of tools, is an open source command line XML inspector for generating useful summaries from large amounts of well-formed XML data. It is particularly valuable when exploring, migrating or cleaning XML, in addition to evaluating schema emergence. This tool require a Java 1.4 or later compatible virtual machine and Maven 2.0 or above to run. Gadget is no longer maintained, but information about it is still available via the Internet Archive.
name: SIMILE Widgets: Gadget

data_tapor: {"id":118,"user_id":1,"name":"Versioning Machine","detail":"\u003cp\u003eThe Versioning Machine, now in version 4.0, is a framework and an interface for displaying multiple versions of text, and encodes the text according to TEI guidelines. It incorporates features found in both critical editions and electronic publication, in addition to providing an environment for textual editors to comparatively view the results of their edits. This tool may be downloaded for use on a local machine, or hosted on one's server for web usage.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/118.jpg","creators_name":"Susan Schreibman","creators_email":"schreibs@tcd.ie","creators_url":"http://www.tcd.ie/English/staff/academic-staff/susan-schriebman.php","star_average":0.0,"url":"http://v-machine.org/","last_updated":"2018-10-17","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/118-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: The Versioning Machine, now in version 4.0, is a framework and an interface for displaying multiple versions of text, and encodes the text according to TEI guidelines. It incorporates features found in both critical editions and electronic publication, in addition to providing an environment for textual editors to comparatively view the results of their edits. This tool may be downloaded for use on a local machine, or hosted on one's server for web usage.
name: Versioning Machine

detail: WordSmith Tools is a commercial integrated suite of programs designed to analyze word behaviour in a text. It can be used to generate a list of all words or word clusters, concord, find keywords and more. This tool is recommended for publishers, language teachers and students, and language researchers.
name: WordSmith

data_tapor: {"id":120,"user_id":null,"name":"Apache Open NLP","detail":"\u003cp\u003eApache OpenNLP is a free, open source toolkit for processing natural language text, based on machine learning. detail: Apache OpenNLP is a free, open source toolkit for processing natural language text, based on machine learning. It includes common natural language processing functions such as tokenization, sentence segmentation, part-of-speech tagging, named entity extraction, chunking, parsing, and coreference resolution.
name: Apache OpenNLP

data_tapor: {"id":121,"user_id":null,"name":"Apache UIMA","detail":"\u003cp\u003eApache UIMA (Unstructured Information Management application) is a software system for analyzing large amounts of unstructured data, such as a plain text document, and identifying entities, such as persons, places, organizations, or relations between entities. Discrete components (written in Java or C++) may be used within the application, such as language identification or entitiy detection. Each component provides self-describing metadata via XML descriptor files.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/121.jpg","creators_name":"The Apache Software Foundation","creators_email":"","creators_url":"http://www.apache.org/","star_average":0.0,"url":"http://uima.apache.org/","last_updated":"2018-10-30","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/121-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: Apache UIMA (Unstructured Information Management application) is a software system for analyzing large amounts of unstructured data, such as a plain text document, and identifying entities, such as persons, places, organizations, or relations between entities. Discrete components (written in Java or C++) may be used within the application, such as language identification or entitiy detection. Each component provides self-describing metadata via XML descriptor files.
name: Apache UIMA

data_tapor: {"id":122,"user_id":1,"name":"Cytoscape","detail":"\u003cp\u003eCytoscape is an open source software platform for visualizing data networks and pathways. Though designed for bioinformatic systems, it has been generalized to complex network analysis and has applications extending to the semantic web. Its core distribution has basic features for data integration and visualization, with additional features available via Java-based plugins.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/122.jpg","creators_name":"Cytoscape Consortium","creators_email":"","creators_url":"http://www.cytoscape.org/","star_average":0.0,"url":"http://cytoscape.org/","last_updated":"2018-10-05","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/122-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: Cytoscape is an open source software platform for visualizing data networks and pathways. Though designed for bioinformatic systems, it has been generalized to complex network analysis and has applications extending to the semantic web. Its core distribution has basic features for data integration and visualization, with additional features available via Java-based plugins.
name: Cytoscape

data_tapor: {"id":123,"user_id":null,"name":"DocuBurst","detail":"\u003cp\u003eDocuBurst is a free web-based visualization tool for exploring the contents of a text.  Visitors can upload their own text or view those provided by others. DocuBurst presents an interactive chart called a ‘radial sunburst’ diagram which organizes the nouns extracted from the user-supplied text based on their meaning, and colours them based on frequency, revealing common themes in the text.  The visualization also shows the proper nouns (e.g. character names) in a linked word cloud. The visualization may be zoomed, filtered, or refocused to target types of words of interest (e.g. “animal” words or “feeling” words).  The visualization also provides a comparison tool to contrast word use across two documents.  DocuBurst views can be bookmarked, annotated, shared, and embedded in your own website.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/123.jpg","creators_name":"Christopher Collins, Sheelagh Carpendale, Gerald Penn, Brittany Kondo and Bradley Chicoine","creators_email":"christopher.collins@uoit.ca","creators_url":"http://faculty.uoit.ca/collins/","star_average":0.0,"url":"http://vialab.science.uoit.ca/portfolio/docuburst","last_updated":"2018-09-27","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/123-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: DocuBurst is a free web-based visualization tool for exploring the contents of a text.  Visitors can upload their own text or view those provided by others. DocuBurst presents an interactive chart called a ‘radial sunburst’ diagram which organizes the nouns extracted from the user-supplied text based on their meaning, and colours them based on frequency, revealing common themes in the text.  The visualization also shows the proper nouns (e.g. character names) in a linked word cloud. The visualization may be zoomed, filtered, or refocused to target types of words of interest (e.g. “animal” words or “feeling” words).  The visualization also provides a comparison tool to contrast word use across two documents.  DocuBurst views can be bookmarked, annotated, shared, and embedded in your own website.
name: DocuBurst

name: EURAC: Comparison Arcs

detail: Corpus Clouds is a free Java demo of a novel interface to a corpus query engine. It aims to aid the user in exploratory search by providing visual information about frequency and distribution of search results in combination with the standard KWIC elements.

data_tapor: {"id":126,"user_id":null,"name":"EURAC: Double Tree","detail":"\u003cp\u003eDouble Tree is a free, open source Java application providing a visualization component for supporting exploratory corpus analysis. It focuses particularly on analyzing concordances, and can also represent a KWIC for a single word by collapsing the contexts into a double sided tree. Each side of the tree can be expanded independently to browse the results.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/126.jpg","creators_name":"Eurac Research","creators_email":"appliedlinguisticsdevs@eurac.edu","creators_url":"https://www.eurac.edu/linguistics/","star_average":0.0,"url":"","last_updated":"2022-06-18","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/126-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: Double Tree is a free, open source Java application providing a visualization component for supporting exploratory corpus analysis. It focuses particularly on analyzing concordances, and can also represent a KWIC for a single word by collapsing the contexts into a double sided tree. Each side of the tree can be expanded independently to browse the results.
name: EURAC: Double Tree

data_tapor: {"id":127,"user_id":null,"name":"EURAC: End to End","detail":"\u003cp\u003eEnd to End is a visualization application for exploratory corpus analysis focused on collocations. detail: End to End is a visualization application for exploratory corpus analysis focused on collocations. This tool starts with two words and constructs a visual network of all collocations of those words within the corpus, while its interface enables interactive zooming and browsing of the resultant graph. name: EURAC: End to End

data_tapor: {"id":129,"user_id":null,"name":"Letter-Pairs Analysis","detail":"\u003cp\u003eLetter-Pairs Analysis is a free, web-based tool for calculating and visualizing the number of times a pair of letters appears in a given text. detail: Letter-Pairs Analysis is a free, web-based tool for calculating and visualizing the number of times a pair of letters appears in a given text. Each pair is represented as a 'bubble', sized according to how frequently that pair appears in the text. An HTML5 version is also now available. Note: this tool forms the basis of Voyant Bubbles.

data_tapor: {"id":130,"user_id":1,"name":"Processing","detail":"\u003cp\u003eProcessing is a free, open source programming language and development library for the visual arts. It is a software sketchbook, a way to visually learn programming fundamentals, and a tool for creating finished professional work, including mapping networks, textual analysis and producing visualizations. detail: Processing is a free, open source programming language and development library for the visual arts. It is a software sketchbook, a way to visually learn programming fundamentals, and a tool for creating finished professional work, including mapping networks, textual analysis and producing visualizations. It runs under Windows, OSX and Linux environments, and can export graphics and applets in a variety of formats.
name: Processing

detail: SEASR's OpenNLP Entities to Protovis Network Graph is a free tool for extracting entities within a specified sentence distance within a text. detail: SEASR's Google Search To Entities To Protovis Network Graph is a free tool for submitting a search to Google and returning a specified number of documents for further processing. It then analyses the documents for connections within a specified number of sentences, and generates a link node network graph using Protovis from the results. detail: PaperToolkit is a free, open source toolkit for designing pen and paper applications. detail: Muse is a free, open source JavaScript tool for reflecting on and searching for patterns in the past by examining one's personal e-mail archive. It analyses e-mail to generate several views including a sentiment graph from messages that may reflect particular emotions or feelings, inferred groups based on communications with various contacts, a calendar view, or an an attachment wall of all documents attached to e-mails.
name: Stanford Mobisocial Lab: Muse

It is multi-platform and easy to deploy and use.\n\nAntConc is part of a suite of related tools for text processing and analysis, including applications for parallel corpus analysis, word profiling, PDF to text conversion, text structure analysis, detecting and converting character encodings, Japanese and Chinese segmenter and tokenizer, wordclass tagger, and spelling variant anaysis. The developer is currently drafting a more explicit licence for the use of the software.","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/148.jpg","creators_name":"Laurence Anthony","creators_email":"anthony@waseda.jp","creators_url":"http://www.antlab.sci.waseda.ac.jp/index.html","star_average":0.0,"url":"http://www.laurenceanthony.net/software/antconc/","last_updated":"2019-08-19","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/148-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail:
AntConc is free concordance software. It is multi-platform and easy to deploy and use.

AntConc is part of a suite of related tools for text processing and analysis, including applications for parallel corpus analysis, word profiling, PDF to text conversion, text structure analysis, detecting and converting character encodings, Japanese and Chinese segmenter and tokenizer, wordclass tagger, and spelling variant anaysis. The developer is currently drafting a more explicit licence for the use of the software.
name: AntConc

detail: CLAWS (Constituent Likelihood Automatic Word-tagging System) is a free parts-of-speech tagging tool from Lancaster University. It has been continuously developed since the 1980s, has consistently achieved 96-97% accuracy, and has been applied to the over 100 million word British National Corpus. This tool is available for download in addition to an on-line 'trial' version.
name: CLAWS (linguistics)

data_tapor: {"id":161,"user_id":null,"name":"Old Bailey Data Warehousing Interface","detail":"\u003cp\u003eThis prototype was produced as a proof-of-concept for the \u003ca title=\"Criminal Intent\" href=\"http://www.criminalintent.org\"\u003eCriminal Intent\u003c/a\u003e project.  It allows the records of the \u003ca title=\"Old Bailey Online\" href=\"http://www.oldbaileyonline.org\"\u003eOld Bailey Online\u003c/a\u003e project to be searched such that the returned results can be viewed as either a timeline or a concordance of terms.  The tool allows for reasonably complex queries to be placed and a range of different formats for the returned charts to be selected.  The tool is primarily built with Python and SQLite and makes use of the Google Chart API for some output options.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/161.jpg","creators_name":"John Simpson","creators_email":"john.simpson@ualberta.ca","creators_url":"http://ra.tapor.ualberta.ca/~digging2data/","star_average":3.0,"url":"http://analytics.artsrn.ualberta.ca/digging2data/","last_updated":"2018-11-07","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/161-thumb.jpg","rating_count":1,"recipes":""}
detail: This prototype was produced as a proof-of-concept for the Criminal Intent project.  It allows the records of the Old Bailey Online project to be searched such that the returned results can be viewed as either a timeline or a concordance of terms.  The tool allows for reasonably complex queries to be placed and a range of different formats for the returned charts to be selected.  The tool is primarily built with Python and SQLite and makes use of the Google Chart API for some output options.
name: Old Bailey Data Warehousing Interface

data_tapor: {"id":162,"user_id":null,"name":"I Write Like","detail":"\u003cp\u003eI Write Like is a free, web-based text analysis tool that compares a user-provided text to the prose of well-known writers using statistics, word choice and writing style analysis. It then reports on which writer the text most resembles. The tool requires at least two paragraphs of text for best results. At this time, the results are limited to the name of a writer, without offering more detailed insight into the analysis; the tool appears to be offered primarily to promote the Memoires journaling software.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/162.jpg","creators_name":"Coding Robots","creators_email":"iwl@codingrobots.com","creators_url":"http://www.codingrobots.com/","star_average":1.5,"url":"http://iwl.me/","last_updated":"2018-09-18","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/162-thumb.jpg","rating_count":2,"recipes":""}
detail: I Write Like is a free, web-based text analysis tool that compares a user-provided text to the prose of well-known writers using statistics, word choice and writing style analysis. It then reports on which writer the text most resembles. The tool requires at least two paragraphs of text for best results. At this time, the results are limited to the name of a writer, without offering more detailed insight into the analysis; the tool appears to be offered primarily to promote the Memoires journaling software.
name: I Write Like

data_tapor: {"id":163,"user_id":1,"name":"Bookworm","detail":"\u003cp\u003eBookworm is a free tool from the Harvard Cultural Observatory designed to generate data from searches on the Open Library and Internet Archives' collections of public domain books. It allows users to search keywords, including in multiple languages simultaneously, and narrow terms by country, gender, subject and header. At present, Bookworm is restricted to searching books published between 1820 and 1920 due to availabliity. The tool produces a graph showing instances of each keyword over time, enabling easy comparison of results.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/163.jpg","creators_name":"Harvard Cultural Observatory","creators_email":"","creators_url":"http://www.culturomics.org/","star_average":0.0,"url":"http://bookworm.culturomics.org/","last_updated":"2018-10-30","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/163-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: Bookworm is a free tool from the Harvard Cultural Observatory designed to generate data from searches on the Open Library and Internet Archives' collections of public domain books. It allows users to search keywords, including in multiple languages simultaneously, and narrow terms by country, gender, subject and header. At present, Bookworm is restricted to searching books published between 1820 and 1920 due to availabliity. The tool produces a graph showing instances of each keyword over time, enabling easy comparison of results.
name: Bookworm

It can be run in a browser (optimized for Chrome and Safari) or downloaded for local installation. It can be used for a variety of annotation tasks, from identitifying natural language entities to chunking to adding metadata.
name: brat rapid annotation tool

detail: CATMA (Computer Aided Textual Markup and Analysis) is a free, open source markup and analysis tool from the University of Hamburg's Department of Languages, Literature and Media. It incorporates three interactive modules, a tagger enabling textual markup and markup editing, an analyzer incorporating a query language and predefined functions, and a query builder that allows users to construct queries from combinations of pre-defined questions while allowing for manual modification for more specific questions. It also interfaces with the Voyant toolset. As of version 4.1, CATMA is a web application with collaborative work functions, and improvements to its user interface, queries and corpus analysis capacity.
name: CATMA (Computer Aided Textual Markup and Analysis)

data_tapor: {"id":167,"user_id":1,"name":"PhiloLogic","detail":"\u003cp\u003ePhilologic is a free, open source full-text search, retrieval and analysis tool developed by the ARTFL Project and the Digital Library Development Centre, at the University of Chicago. This tool supports a wide variety of XML and SGML encoded documents, in addition to plain text, Dublin Core and HTML, and includes a MySQL back end. detail: Philologic is a free, open source full-text search, retrieval and analysis tool developed by the ARTFL Project and the Digital Library Development Centre, at the University of Chicago. This tool supports a wide variety of XML and SGML encoded documents, in addition to plain text, Dublin Core and HTML, and includes a MySQL back end. It is designed ot be light, fast and robust, boasts extensive use and testing, and can be used directly 'out of the box' with numerous configuration options built in.
name: PhiloLogic

data_tapor: {"id":168,"user_id":1,"name":"FromThePage","detail":"\u003cp\u003eFromThePage is a free software for manuscript transcription, allowing volunteers to transcribe document pages online. Transcriptions can then be marked up and annotated in a wiki-like enviroment, with the resultant text displayed on the public web. It includes a discussion environment, enabling collaboration on particularly difficult pages. FromThePage is currently in beta, permitting up to 100 pages per project, and is in the process of developing a paid version for larger projects requiring more server space, with price determined primarily by server and maintenance costs. Privacy features are also under development, and further features forthcoming based on feedback from users.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/168.jpg","creators_name":"Ben Brumfield","creators_email":"benwbrum@gmail.com","creators_url":"http://beta.fromthepage.com/","star_average":0.0,"url":"http://beta.fromthepage.com/","last_updated":"2018-10-12","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/168-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: FromThePage is a free software for manuscript transcription, allowing volunteers to transcribe document pages online. Transcriptions can then be marked up and annotated in a wiki-like enviroment, with the resultant text displayed on the public web. It includes a discussion environment, enabling collaboration on particularly difficult pages. FromThePage is currently in beta, permitting up to 100 pages per project, and is in the process of developing a paid version for larger projects requiring more server space, with price determined primarily by server and maintenance costs. Privacy features are also under development, and further features forthcoming based on feedback from users.
name: FromThePage

data_tapor: {"id":169,"user_id":1,"name":"GapVis","detail":"\u003cp\u003eGapVis is a free tool developed in conjunction with Google Ancient Places to visualize the locations within and allow the exploration of books referencing ancient places within the Google Books collection. detail: GapVis is a free tool developed in conjunction with Google Ancient Places to visualize the locations within and allow the exploration of books referencing ancient places within the Google Books collection. Users can view text summaries, use an enhanced reading interface and explore the location references through a place detail view. It is intended both to enable location-based text discovery, and to allow users to delve more deeply into a text based on the locations referenced within it. GapVis is currently in beta.
name: GapVis

detail: Sophie is a free, creative commons authoring tool from the Institute for the Future of the Book and the University of Southern California's School of Cinematic Arts that enables collaboration, reading and publication. Its highlights include an authoring environment that allows users to create complex networked multimedia documents, a reader than opens books in a browser without downloading additional software, comment frames for adding discussions within books, digital libraries compatible with the Sophe iPad app, timeline creation and collaborative book creation. As of version 2.1, Sophie includes HTML5 export for data integrating multimedia content and for use on a wide variety of devices.

detail: Textalyser is a free web-based text analysis tool offered by the Bernhard Huber Internet Engineering Company. Users can paste text into the provided entry field, upload a file or provide a URL for analysis. Textalyser provides detailed statistics on the text to determine subject, analyse word groupings, determine keyword density and deterimine the most prominent phrase. detail: TextSTAT is a free text analysis tool offered by Niederländische Philologie, FU Berlin. It is a simple program designed to accept plain text, HTML, Word and OpenOffice files to produce word frequency lists and concordances, and versions are available in English, German, Dutch, Portugese, Spanish, French, Italian, Galician, Finnish, Polish and Czech. TextSTAT also includes a web spider and news reader for adding web pages and news to a corpus.
name: TextSTAT

It offers multi-window frames, overviews generated through interactive network views utilizing visual interconnections, and cloud views and reports. A free demo version is also availalble, and does not include a time limit. This tool was first developed in 1989 and has been in continous development since. data_tapor: {"id":185,"user_id":1,"name":"CollateX","detail":"\u003cp\u003eCollateX is a free Java library for collating texts offered by Interedition, designed to be the successor to Peter Robinson's Collate. It uses a component-oriented architecture, to enable users to mix and match components according to their needs. detail: CollateX is a free Java library for collating texts offered by Interedition, designed to be the successor to Peter Robinson's Collate. It uses a component-oriented architecture, to enable users to mix and match components according to their needs. Though its core library is Java, it also integrates a demo web application, a demo client application and Python language bindings that allow CollateX to be embedded into Python applications.
name: CollateX

data_tapor: {"id":186,"user_id":1,"name":"cue.language","detail":"\u003cp\u003ecue.language is a free library of Java code and resources for basic natural language processing emerging from the development of the Wordle word cloud tool and maintained by Jonathan Feinman of IBM's CUE Research Group. detail: cue.language is a free library of Java code and resources for basic natural language processing emerging from the development of the Wordle word cloud tool and maintained by Jonathan Feinman of IBM's CUE Research Group. Its functions include tokenization, counting strings, detecting the script alphabet or writing system required to represent the text, guess the text's language and customizeable stop word detection.
name: cue.language

detail: CulturalAnalytics, also known as Cultural Analytics for the Digital Humanities in R, is a free R package of functions for statistical analysis and plotting image properties, developed by Rob Myers specifically for the Digital Humanities, and of value to anyone else with an interest in examining digital or digitized images. name: CulturalAnalytics

data_tapor: {"id":194,"user_id":1,"name":"TXM","detail":"\u003cp\u003eTXM is a free, open source text corpus analysis environment. detail: TXM is a free, open source text corpus analysis environment. Its features include concordance, collocate search, frequencies based on the CQP full text search engine and statistical functions based on R packages. It can export results in CSV, XML or SVG format, and runs as a standalone desktop application in Windows, OS X and Linux environments, or as a web portal (download the leaflet for more).
name: TXM

data_tapor: {"id":198,"user_id":1,"name":"Abbot","detail":"\u003cp\u003eAbbot is a free tool for converting multiple XML texts with multiple markup schema into a common interoperable file, offered by the MONK (Metadata Offer New Knowledge) Project. It can also read an XML schema file and output procedures, and use them to convert other files into valid XML in alignment with the target schema. While Abbot focusses on TEI, it has been designed to flexibly accomodate other standards and can transform texts into any XML schema required.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/198.jpg","creators_name":"Brian Pytlik-Zillig, Stephen Ramsay, and Martin Mueller (MONK Project)","creators_email":"monkproject@lis.illinois.edu","creators_url":"http://www.monkproject.org/","star_average":0.0,"url":"https://github.com/CDRH/abbot","last_updated":"2014-11-20","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/198-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: Abbot is a free tool for converting multiple XML texts with multiple markup schema into a common interoperable file, offered by the MONK (Metadata Offer New Knowledge) Project. It can also read an XML schema file and output procedures, and use them to convert other files into valid XML in alignment with the target schema. While Abbot focusses on TEI, it has been designed to flexibly accomodate other standards and can transform texts into any XML schema required.
name: Abbot

data_tapor: {"id":199,"user_id":null,"name":"TACT (Text Analysis Computing Tools)","detail":"\u003cp\u003eTACT (Text Analysis Computing Tools) is a historically important text analysis and retrieval system that was developed from 1986 to 1989 at the University of Toronto in cooperation with IBM and remained in use into the 1990s. It was designed to run in MS-DOS and permitted inquiries on text databases in a number of European languages. Originally available on two 1.44MB floppy disks, the full fileset is now available for free download.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/199.jpg","creators_name":"John Bradley, Ian Lancashire, Lidio Presutti, and Michael Stairs","creators_email":"","creators_url":"http://projects.chass.utoronto.ca/tact/","star_average":0.0,"url":"http://projects.chass.utoronto.ca/tact/","last_updated":"2021-02-05","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"https://github.com/johnBradley501/TACT","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/199-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: TACT (Text Analysis Computing Tools) is a historically important text analysis and retrieval system that was developed from 1986 to 1989 at the University of Toronto in cooperation with IBM and remained in use into the 1990s. It was designed to run in MS-DOS and permitted inquiries on text databases in a number of European languages. Originally available on two 1.44MB floppy disks, the full fileset is now available for free download.
name: TACT (Text Analysis Computing Tools)

data_tapor: {"id":201,"user_id":null,"name":"TUSTEP","detail":"\u003cp\u003eTUSTEP (Tubingen System of Text Processing Tools) is a free, open source, widely-used toolbox for text processing. detail: TUSTEP (Tubingen System of Text Processing Tools) is a free, open source, widely-used toolbox for text processing. It is aimed at scholarly audiences, can work with texts in both latin and non-latin scripts, and is primarily designed for humanites applications. Its modules include data capture, information retrieval, text collation, text analysis, sorting and ordering, rule-based textual manipulation, data export and typesetting. The user manual is only available in German at this time. This tool has been in continuous development since the 1960s.
name: TUSTEP

name: INTEX

data_tapor: {"id":214,"user_id":null,"name":"Micro-OCP","detail":"\u003cp\u003eMicro-OCP (Oxford Concordance Program) was a major and historically important textual analysis tool for microprocessor computers. It enabled users to generate concordances, word lists and indexes, in addition to facilitating text markup in COCOA or other markup languages. Micro-OCP was written in FORTRAN, ran primarily in a DOS environment and could be ported to other operating systems including UNIX.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/214.jpg","creators_name":"CTI Centre for Textual Studies (Oxford University)","creators_email":"","creators_url":"http://users.ox.ac.uk/~ctitext2/","star_average":0.0,"url":"http://users.ox.ac.uk/~ctitext2/resguide/resources/o125.html","last_updated":"2013-01-21","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/214-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: Micro-OCP (Oxford Concordance Program) was a major and historically important textual analysis tool for microprocessor computers. It enabled users to generate concordances, word lists and indexes, in addition to facilitating text markup in COCOA or other markup languages. Micro-OCP was written in FORTRAN, ran primarily in a DOS environment and could be ported to other operating systems including UNIX.
name: Micro-OCP

data_tapor: {"id":215,"user_id":null,"name":"FINNMORF","detail":"\u003cp\u003eFINNMORF was a tool for generating full lexical paradigms for Finnish words. It modelled Finnish morphological competence, to facilitate identification of the most likely forms of a word within its context. Although the program could not select the correct form from context, the complexity of Finnish required sophisticated modelling to correctly determine the possible root form of a given word. As such, FINNMORF represented a significant contribution to computational linguistics.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/215.jpg","creators_name":"Eugene Holman","creators_email":"","creators_url":"","star_average":0.0,"url":"","last_updated":"2018-10-30","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/215-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: FINNMORF was a tool for generating full lexical paradigms for Finnish words. It modelled Finnish morphological competence, to facilitate identification of the most likely forms of a word within its context. Although the program could not select the correct form from context, the complexity of Finnish required sophisticated modelling to correctly determine the possible root form of a given word. As such, FINNMORF represented a significant contribution to computational linguistics.
name: FINNMORF

data_tapor: {"id":225,"user_id":null,"name":"Massive Pixel Environment","detail":"\u003cp\u003eMassive Pixel Environment (formerly Most Pixels Ever: Cluster Edition) is a library from the Texas Advanced Computing Center's A Thousand Words Project, inspired by and expanding on the original Most Pixels Ever developed by Daniel Shiffman. detail: Massive Pixel Environment (formerly Most Pixels Ever: Cluster Edition) is a library from the Texas Advanced Computing Center's A Thousand Words Project, inspired by and expanding on the original Most Pixels Ever developed by Daniel Shiffman. It extends Processing sketches to multi-node tile displays, enabling users to display output across multiple systems and displays, at the native resolution of those displays. data_tapor: {"id":230,"user_id":null,"name":"FRANTEXT / Stella","detail":"\u003cp\u003eFRANTEXT is a historically and culturally important database of French literary, philosophical and technical texts with an emphasis on diversity and representation, spanning the Middle Ages to the present, and offered on a subscription basis. This resource is aimed at linguists and literary scholars in the humanities and social sciences, and is notable for its inclusion of a powerful search engine called Stella. Stella is a sophisticated NLP search suite, and includes regular expression search, lemmatization, vocabulary list and entity categorization functions.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/230.jpg","creators_name":"ATILF - CNRS","creators_email":"frantext@atilf.fr","creators_url":"http://www.atilf.fr/","star_average":0.0,"url":"http://www.frantext.fr/","last_updated":"2018-10-30","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/230-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: FRANTEXT is a historically and culturally important database of French literary, philosophical and technical texts with an emphasis on diversity and representation, spanning the Middle Ages to the present, and offered on a subscription basis. This resource is aimed at linguists and literary scholars in the humanities and social sciences, and is notable for its inclusion of a powerful search engine called Stella. Stella is a sophisticated NLP search suite, and includes regular expression search, lemmatization, vocabulary list and entity categorization functions.
name: FRANTEXT / Stella

data_tapor: {"id":231,"user_id":null,"name":"TACTweb 1.0","detail":"\u003cp\u003eTACTweb 1.0 is a free, historically important experimental web-based implementation of the TACT (Text Analysis Computing Tools) analysis and retrieval system, utilizing code originally written for TACT 2.0. TACTweb 1.0 is designed to make a TACT TDB database accessible to web users without requiring them to have a copy of TACT themselves. TACTweb 1.0 enables users to query TACT in its query language without having to learn the rest of the system. It is currently available for download, and is intended for install on a server.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/231.jpg","creators_name":"John Bradley and Geoffrey Rockwell","creators_email":"john.bradley@kcl.ac.uk","creators_url":"http://www.kcl.ac.uk/artshums/depts/ddh/people/academic/bradley/index.aspx","star_average":0.0,"url":"http://tactweb.cch.kcl.ac.uk","last_updated":"2018-11-06","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/231-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: TACTweb 1.0 is a free, historically important experimental web-based implementation of the TACT (Text Analysis Computing Tools) analysis and retrieval system, utilizing code originally written for TACT 2.0. TACTweb 1.0 is designed to make a TACT TDB database accessible to web users without requiring them to have a copy of TACT themselves. TACTweb 1.0 enables users to query TACT in its query language without having to learn the rest of the system. It is currently available for download, and is intended for install on a server.
name: TACTweb 1.0

detail: The General Inquirer is a historically important program for content analysis of textual data originally developed in the 1960s by Philip Stone and his colleagues at the Harvard Laboratory of Social Relations. Though the original release used punched cards, a version the program is available by request, and can be obtained by e-mailing Roger Hurwitz from an academic address. A minimalist web version capable of processing small files is also available. The General Inquirer's homepage is maintained in Philip Stone's memory.
name: General Inquirer
