data_tapor: {"id":271,"user_id":null,"name":"Morfogen, Morffile/Morfword, Inflword (Version 2.0)","detail":"\u003cp\u003eMorfogen, Morffile/Morfword and Inflword were four historicially important interrelated tools offered as and designed to operate as single package. Morfogen is a finite state compiler for morphological analysis, while Morffile and Morfword utilize Morfogen's compiled rules. Morffile searches a text and replaces them with either their base form or a base form followed by morpheme names. Morfword takes a word input by the user and generates its base forms and morpheme names. Inflword generates inflected words.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/271.jpg","creators_name":"Executive Communication Systems, Inc.","creators_email":"","creators_url":"","star_average":0.0,"url":"","last_updated":"2014-12-31","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/271-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: Morfogen, Morffile/Morfword and Inflword were four historicially important interrelated tools offered as and designed to operate as single package. Morfogen is a finite state compiler for morphological analysis, while Morffile and Morfword utilize Morfogen's compiled rules. Morffile searches a text and replaces them with either their base form or a base form followed by morpheme names. Morfword takes a word input by the user and generates its base forms and morpheme names. Inflword generates inflected words.
name: Morfogen, Morffile/Morfword, Inflword (Version 2.0)

detail: Prism is a visualization tool that represents texts based on crowdsourced interpretations. Users are encouraged to highlight words in a text according to categories ("facets"). name: Prism

detail: ANNIS (ANNotation of Information Structure), now in version 3.4.3, is an open source browser-based visualization architecture designed to annotate complex multilevel linguistic corpora. detail: DocuScope is a text analysis environment first developed in 1998. It contains a suite of interactive visualization tools for corpus-based rhetorical analysis. Users could input a web address, upload a file or directly enter text for analysis. HyperPo's interface was available in both English and French. data_tapor: {"id":317,"user_id":null,"name":"PRORA","detail":"\u003cp\u003ePRORA was a historically important set of six interrelated programs for creating computerized concordances, first released in the 1960s. It output on punched cards, could be used for any language represented by the Latin alphabet, and also had functions for generating word lists and annotating texts. Glickman and Staalman desgined PRORA to reduce the requirement for researchers to learn computers to use them in their literary studies.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/317.jpg","creators_name":"Robert Jay Glickman and Gerrit Joseph Staalman","creators_email":"","creators_url":"","star_average":0.0,"url":"","last_updated":"2013-12-18","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/317-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: PRORA was a historically important set of six interrelated programs for creating computerized concordances, first released in the 1960s. It output on punched cards, could be used for any language represented by the Latin alphabet, and also had functions for generating word lists and annotating texts. Glickman and Staalman desgined PRORA to reduce the requirement for researchers to learn computers to use them in their literary studies.
name: PRORA

detail: SCAN was a conversational programming language available in the 1970s for text analysis. data_tapor: {"id":320,"user_id":null,"name":"SATO (Systeme d'analyse des textes par ordinateur)","detail":"\u003cp\u003eSATO (Systeme d'analyse des textes par ordinateur) is a longstanding historic text analysis system, now available as a free, web-based tool. Users can either draw off SATO's corpus or upload their own for analysis, and the texts for analysis may be in French, English or Spanish. name_tapor-api: SATO (Systeme d'analyse des textes par ordinateur)
detail: SATO (Systeme d'analyse des textes par ordinateur) is a longstanding historic text analysis system, now available as a free, web-based tool. Users can either draw off SATO's corpus or upload their own for analysis, and the texts for analysis may be in French, English or Spanish. It can perform standard text analysis functions such as word frequencies, comparisons, tokenizing and keyword in context, and has predefined filters for searches.
name: SATO (Systeme d'analyse des textes par ordinateur)

data_tapor: {"id":328,"user_id":null,"name":"INL BlackLab","detail":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eFrom the official BlackLab site:\u003c/strong\u003e \"BlackLab is a corpus retrieval engine built on top of Apache Lucene. It allows fast, complex searches with accurate hit highlighting on large, tagged and annotated, bodies of text. It was developed at the Institute of Dutch Lexicology (INL) to provide a fast and feature-rich search interface on our historical and contemporary text corpora.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eBlackLab is licensed under the Apache License 2.0.\"\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eBlackLab is not an end-user application, but an extension to Apache Lucene.  It requires programming experience to use.  Several sites have so far been built using BlackLab.  The BlackLab FAQ at https://github.com/INL/BlackLab/wiki/Frequently-Asked-Questions lists several of these.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eBlackLab is very useful as search engine for morphologically adorned corpora.  The principal search language syntax is similar to that of traditional corpus search engine tools such as the Corpus Workbench or the Sketch Engine.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003e \u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003e \u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/328.jpg","creators_name":"Institute of Dutch Lexicology","creators_email":"jan.niestadt@inl.nl","creators_url":"","star_average":0.0,"url":"https://github.com/INL/BlackLab","last_updated":"2018-11-07","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/328-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: From the official BlackLab site: "BlackLab is a corpus retrieval engine built on top of Apache Lucene. It allows fast, complex searches with accurate hit highlighting on large, tagged and annotated, bodies of text. It was developed at the Institute of Dutch Lexicology (INL) to provide a fast and feature-rich search interface on our historical and contemporary text corpora. BlackLab is licensed under the Apache License 2.0." BlackLab is not an end-user application, but an extension to Apache Lucene.  It requires programming experience to use.  Several sites have so far been built using BlackLab.  The BlackLab FAQ at https://github.com/INL/BlackLab/wiki/Frequently-Asked-Questions lists several of these. BlackLab is very useful as search engine for morphologically adorned corpora.  The principal search language syntax is similar to that of traditional corpus search engine tools such as the Corpus Workbench or the Sketch Engine.
name: INL BlackLab

data_tapor: {"id":333,"user_id":null,"name":"The Chicago Homer","detail":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe Chicago Homer is a multilingual database that uses the search and display capabilities of electronic texts to make the distinctive features of Early Greek epic accessible to readers with and without Greek. Except for fragments, it contains all the texts of these poems in the original Greek. In addition, the Chicago Homer includes English and German translations, in particular Lattimore's Iliad, James Huddleston's Odyssey, Daryl Hine's translations of Hesiod and the Homeric Hymns, and the German translations of the Iliad and Odyssey by Johan Heinrich Voss. Through the associated web site Eumaios users of the Chicago Homer can also from each line of the poem access pertinent Iliad Scholia and papyrus readings.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003e \u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/333.jpg","creators_name":"Ahuvia Kahane and Martin Mueller, editors.  Craig Berry and Bill Parod, technical editors.","creators_email":"","creators_url":"","star_average":0.0,"url":"http://digital.library.northwestern.edu/homer/","last_updated":"2018-11-06","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/333-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: The Chicago Homer is a multilingual database that uses the search and display capabilities of electronic texts to make the distinctive features of Early Greek epic accessible to readers with and without Greek. Except for fragments, it contains all the texts of these poems in the original Greek. In addition, the Chicago Homer includes English and German translations, in particular Lattimore's Iliad, James Huddleston's Odyssey, Daryl Hine's translations of Hesiod and the Homeric Hymns, and the German translations of the Iliad and Odyssey by Johan Heinrich Voss. Through the associated web site Eumaios users of the Chicago Homer can also from each line of the poem access pertinent Iliad Scholia and papyrus readings.
name: The Chicago Homer

detail: Text Variation Explorer (TVE) is a Java tool for text visualization. TVE enables users to explore the effect of window size on a text's type-token ratio, proportion of hapax legomena and average word length; it can also cluster text fragments based on principal component analysis and has text comparison features. TVE is in beta and is presented 'as is'.
name: Text Variation Explorer (TVE)

data_tapor: {"id":349,"user_id":null,"name":"BookLamp","detail":"\u003cp\u003eBookLamp, part of the Book Genome Project, is a tool and a resource for finding books. It offers an alternative to social recommendation engines reliant on author popularity by treating its books as equal regardless of number of copies sold. BookLamp's goal is to match users to the books relevant to their interests as accurately as possible. Rather than genres, it uses 'StoryDNA', which identifies the thematic ingredients important to a book's narrative, in addition to how prominent that ingredient is within the text.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eBookLamp has been retired as of April 2014 and the website is no longer available. The site has been captured by the Internet Archive, and may still be viewed there via the Wayback Machine.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/349.jpg","creators_name":"Book Genome Project","creators_email":"","creators_url":"http://bookgenome.com/","star_average":4.0,"url":"","last_updated":"2018-10-30","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/349-thumb.jpg","rating_count":2,"recipes":""}
detail: BookLamp, part of the Book Genome Project, is a tool and a resource for finding books. It offers an alternative to social recommendation engines reliant on author popularity by treating its books as equal regardless of number of copies sold. BookLamp's goal is to match users to the books relevant to their interests as accurately as possible. Rather than genres, it uses 'StoryDNA', which identifies the thematic ingredients important to a book's narrative, in addition to how prominent that ingredient is within the text. BookLamp has been retired as of April 2014 and the website is no longer available. The site has been captured by the Internet Archive, and may still be viewed there via the Wayback Machine.
name: BookLamp

detail: BookLamp's Stream Graph Viewer is a tool for viewing where and how much of a story element ('StoryDNA') appears in a book. Books can be searched by title or author, and then graphed for one or several pieces of StoryDNA.
name: BookLamp Labs: Stream Graph Viewer

detail: BookLamp's StoryDNA Viewer is a corpus search tool designed to find all books sharing a user-selected set of characteristics ('StoryDNA'). From the resultant list, users can then view a book's entry in BookLamp to get more information about what characteristics it has, in what proportion, and in relation to other books in the database.
name: BookLamp Labs: StoryDNA Viewer

data_tapor: {"id":352,"user_id":null,"name":"BookLamp Labs: Suggestion Viewer","detail":"\u003cp\u003eBookLamp's Suggestion Viewer is a faceted search and browser tool for finding new books based on how similar they are to another book. Users can search by either title or author and select the book to center the search on. The Suggestion Viewer then generates a radial visualization of other books similar to the central book, showing the strength of the connection by the thickness of the connecting line and characteristic ('StoryDNA'). Users can switch between StoryDNA connections via drop list, and can click on an outer book to recenter the tool on that book.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eBookLamp and its tools have been retired as of April 2014 and the website is no longer available. The main site has been captured by the Internet Archive (\u003ca href=\"https://web.archive.org/web/20140210212627/http://booklamp.org/\"\u003ehttps://web.archive.org/web/20140210212627/http://booklamp.org/\u003c/a\u003e) but this tool is not among the pages available there.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/352.jpg","creators_name":"Book Genome Project","creators_email":"","creators_url":"http://bookgenome.com/","star_average":0.0,"url":"","last_updated":"2018-10-05","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/352-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: BookLamp's Suggestion Viewer is a faceted search and browser tool for finding new books based on how similar they are to another book. Users can search by either title or author and select the book to center the search on. The Suggestion Viewer then generates a radial visualization of other books similar to the central book, showing the strength of the connection by the thickness of the connecting line and characteristic ('StoryDNA'). Users can switch between StoryDNA connections via drop list, and can click on an outer book to recenter the tool on that book. BookLamp and its tools have been retired as of April 2014 and the website is no longer available. The main site has been captured by the Internet Archive (https://web.archive.org/web/20140210212627/http://booklamp.org/) but this tool is not among the pages available there.
name: BookLamp Labs: Suggestion Viewer

detail: Weka (Waikato Environment for Knowledge Analysis) is a free Java-based data mining workbench of machine learning algorithms, offered by the Machine Learning Group of the University of Waikato. data_tapor: {"id":358,"user_id":null,"name":"Tom Sawyer Perspectives","detail":"\u003cp\u003eTom Sawyer Perspectives is a commercial software package for data visualization and analysis. data_tapor: {"id":364,"user_id":null,"name":"Visual Browser","detail":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan\u003eVisual Browser is a Java application for visualizing RDF data using the Jena framework. The resultant graphs are animated and permit users to expand and hide nodes and switch the view of edges, allowing them to focus on a small part of the network. The visualization engine is derived from TouchGraph LLC and follows the navigation approach of WebOFDAV, a system based on the concept of exploratory navigation to reduce chances of getting “lost in hyperspace” situation. \u003c/span\u003e    \u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/364.jpg","creators_name":"Masaryk University Natural Language Processing Centre","creators_email":"xpopelk@fi.muni.cz","creators_url":"http://nlp.fi.muni.cz/","star_average":0.0,"url":"http://nlp.fi.muni.cz/projekty/visualbrowser","last_updated":"2018-10-26","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/364-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: Visual Browser is a Java application for visualizing RDF data using the Jena framework. The resultant graphs are animated and permit users to expand and hide nodes and switch the view of edges, allowing them to focus on a small part of the network. The visualization engine is derived from TouchGraph LLC and follows the navigation approach of WebOFDAV, a system based on the concept of exploratory navigation to reduce chances of getting “lost in hyperspace” situation.
name: Visual Browser

It is designed to provide an overview of RDF data through interactive visualization and exporation. Features include highlighting and filtering, and the tool permits both global and detail views. data_tapor: {"id":368,"user_id":null,"name":"Google Charts","detail":"\u003cp\u003eGoogle Charts (formerly the Google Visualization API) is a web-based interface for interactive data visualization via HTML5 and SVG. detail: Google Charts (formerly the Google Visualization API) is a web-based interface for interactive data visualization via HTML5 and SVG. It includes a number of preset chart types ranging from line charts to word trees and all are customizable. A separate selection of user community contributed chart types is also available. Within a chart, the API identifies events that users can trigger with presets ranging from simple clicks to Javascript methods, and enable users to construct chart dashboards that can be embedded in their website along with the chart proper.
name: Google Charts

detail: Automatic Mapping Among Lexico-Grammatical Annotation Models (AMALGAM) is a free, longstanding tool for tagging text according to part of speech (PoS) from Leeds University. It includes eight PoS tag schemes, and a Multi-Tagged Corpus of samples tagged with various schemas.
name: Automatic Mapping Among Lexico-Grammatical Annotation Models (AMALGAM)

data_tapor: {"id":376,"user_id":null,"name":"TnT (Trigrams'n'Tags)","detail":"\u003cp\u003eTnT, which is short for Trigrams'n'Tags, is a statistical part-of-speech tagger from Universitat de Saarlandes. It can be trained on a variety of corpora and languages, and is based on the Viterbi algorithm for second order Markov models. It includes language models for English and German. This program is only available on request.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/376.jpg","creators_name":"Thorsten Brants, Universitat de Saarlandes Computational Linguistics","creators_email":"","creators_url":"http://www.coli.uni-sb.de/","star_average":0.0,"url":"http://www.coli.uni-saarland.de/~thorsten/tnt/","last_updated":"2013-12-05","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/376-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: TnT, which is short for Trigrams'n'Tags, is a statistical part-of-speech tagger from Universitat de Saarlandes. It can be trained on a variety of corpora and languages, and is based on the Viterbi algorithm for second order Markov models. It includes language models for English and German. This program is only available on request.
name: TnT (Trigrams'n'Tags)

data_tapor: {"id":377,"user_id":null,"name":"YAGO","detail":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan\u003eYAGO is a semantic knowledge base of over 10 million entities, and over 120 million facts about those entities, developed by the Max Planck Institut Informatik. Its base derives from Wikipedia, WordNet and GeoNames, and the accuaracy has not only been manually evaluated, but relations are also provided with an annotation stating its confidence value. The YAGO ontology includes spacial and temporal dimensions, and integrates WordNet's thematic domains as well. It can be queried or browsed right from the website, and the full ontology is available for download. \u003cbr\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/377.jpg","creators_name":"Max Planck Institute for Informatics","creators_email":"NameOfTheOntology@mpi-inf.mpg.de","creators_url":"http://www.mpi-inf.mpg.de/","star_average":0.0,"url":"http://www.mpi-inf.mpg.de/departments/databases-and-information-systems/research/yago-naga/yago/","last_updated":"2018-10-17","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/377-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: YAGO is a semantic knowledge base of over 10 million entities, and over 120 million facts about those entities, developed by the Max Planck Institut Informatik. Its base derives from Wikipedia, WordNet and GeoNames, and the accuaracy has not only been manually evaluated, but relations are also provided with an annotation stating its confidence value. The YAGO ontology includes spacial and temporal dimensions, and integrates WordNet's thematic domains as well. It can be queried or browsed right from the website, and the full ontology is available for download.
name: YAGO

data_tapor: {"id":378,"user_id":1,"name":"Tableau Public","detail":"\u003cp\u003eTableau Public is a free data visualization tool aimed at online publishers and academics. It can be used to create an interactive visualization, and also enables users to publish it to the web as an embed or share it via a link. Users must download the desktop interface, and all projects created through the system are saved remotely to the Tableau Public server rather than to the user's local machine. It is availabe for both Windows and OS X, and has a visual interface with a simple drag and drop process.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/378.jpg","creators_name":"Tableau Software","creators_email":"info-public@tableausoftware.com","creators_url":"http://www.tableausoftware.com/","star_average":0.0,"url":"http://www.tableausoftware.com/public","last_updated":"2018-11-07","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/378-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: Tableau Public is a free data visualization tool aimed at online publishers and academics. It can be used to create an interactive visualization, and also enables users to publish it to the web as an embed or share it via a link. Users must download the desktop interface, and all projects created through the system are saved remotely to the Tableau Public server rather than to the user's local machine. It is availabe for both Windows and OS X, and has a visual interface with a simple drag and drop process.
name: Tableau Software

data_tapor: {"id":385,"user_id":null,"name":"Ngram Statistics Package (NSP)","detail":"\u003cp\u003eThe Ngram Statistics Package (NSP) is a free suite for identifying word and character ngrams in large corpora developed by Ted Pederson and his team. It also generates frequency data and co-occurrences, and can generate correlations between two files. It has been in continuous development since the 1990s and has been used in developing the SenseCluster and Senseval tools.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/385.jpg","creators_name":"Ted Pedersen and the Ngram Development Team, University of Minnesota Duluth","creators_email":"","creators_url":"http://www.d.umn.edu/~tpederse/","star_average":0.0,"url":"http://www.d.umn.edu/~tpederse/nsp.html","last_updated":"2018-03-23","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/385-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: The Ngram Statistics Package (NSP) is a free suite for identifying word and character ngrams in large corpora developed by Ted Pederson and his team. It also generates frequency data and co-occurrences, and can generate correlations between two files. It has been in continuous development since the 1990s and has been used in developing the SenseCluster and Senseval tools.
name: Ngram Statistics Package (NSP)

detail: The UVic Image Markup Tool is a free tool for annotating images and storing the annotations in XML files from the University of Victoria's Humanities Computing and Media Centre. Its interface is designed for users without prior XML experience with additional functions for users familiar with XML, and supports multiple languages. The Image Markup Tool is available for Windows, and will also run in Linux with Wine.

data_tapor: {"id":388,"user_id":null,"name":"JEUDEMO","detail":"\u003cp\u003eJEUDEMO was an information retrieval program developed at the University of Montreal in the 1970s. It built on and extended the functionality of COCOA by including Boolean search functions to search for patterns within a text such as co-occurences, but saw limited adoption as it required texts to be supplied on punched cards or paper tape and was programmed in a language exclusive to the CDC Cyber 74 computer system.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/388.jpg","creators_name":"Paul Bratley, Serge Lusignan and Francine Ouellette at the University of Montreal","creators_email":"","creators_url":"","star_average":0.0,"url":"","last_updated":"2014-01-06","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/388-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: JEUDEMO was an information retrieval program developed at the University of Montreal in the 1970s. It built on and extended the functionality of COCOA by including Boolean search functions to search for patterns within a text such as co-occurences, but saw limited adoption as it required texts to be supplied on punched cards or paper tape and was programmed in a language exclusive to the CDC Cyber 74 computer system.
name: JEUDEMO

data_tapor: {"id":389,"user_id":null,"name":"RATS (Random-Accessible Text Systems)","detail":"\u003cp\u003eRATS (Random-Accessible Text Systems) was a PL/I utility for text analysis developed by John B. Smith of Pennsylvania State Univeristy in the early 1970s. It was aimed at researchers with some experience with programming and aimed to streamline the text analysis process while permitting users to customize the program to suit their work. As a system, Smith promoted RATS for concordences, thematic distributions and transitional matrixes.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/389.jpg","creators_name":"John B. Smith, Pennsylvania State University","creators_email":"","creators_url":"","star_average":0.0,"url":"","last_updated":"2018-10-26","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/389-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: RATS (Random-Accessible Text Systems) was a PL/I utility for text analysis developed by John B. Smith of Pennsylvania State Univeristy in the early 1970s. It was aimed at researchers with some experience with programming and aimed to streamline the text analysis process while permitting users to customize the program to suit their work. As a system, Smith promoted RATS for concordences, thematic distributions and transitional matrixes.
name: RATS (Random-Accessible Text Systems)

detail: LitStats is a tool for statistical analysis of natural language texts developed in the 1980s by Dr. Stephen Reimer of the University of Alberta. From an ASCII text, it can generate word frequency counts, word lengths, initial letter frequencies, sentence length frequencies and verbal segment frequencies. name: LitStats

data_tapor: {"id":399,"user_id":null,"name":"TEXTAN","detail":"\u003cp\u003eTEXTAN was a program developed by Suzanne Hanon of the University of Aarhus in the 1970s for locating English loan words in French texts. detail: TEXTAN was a program developed by Suzanne Hanon of the University of Aarhus in the 1970s for locating English loan words in French texts. It was written in ALGOL 4 and consisted of two programs. TEXTAN 1 learned anglicisms developed manually from French newspapers, while TEXTAN 2 searched a French text and located anglicisms.
name: TEXTAN

detail: Textable is a an add-on tool developed for the Orange data mining and visualization package. Its functions include the ability to build data tables from textual data, to import data from other sources, and to build concordances and collocations. It also enables users to segment and annotate text, systematically recode data, determine subsets, and compute frequency and complexity measures.
name: Textable

data_tapor: {"id":451,"user_id":1,"name":"Overview","detail":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan\u003eOverview is a free, web-based tool for document mining. Developed by and for journalists, Overview is also broadly applicable to other corpus-based research applications. Aside from providing \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href=\"http://overview.ap.org/about/overview.ap.org/blog/2013/12/advanced-search-quoted-phrases-boolean-operators-fuzzy-matching-and-more/\"\u003eadvanced search features\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cspan\u003e such as regular expressions and fuzzy matching, \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eOverview automatically \u003c/span\u003e\u003ca href=\"http://overview.ap.org/blog/2013/04/how-overview-can-organize-thousands-of-documents-for-a-reporter/\"\u003esorts documents according to topic\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan\u003e and provides a fast visualization and reading interface. You can apply tags to search results, individual documents, or entire topics to track what you've found, then export the entire document set with its tags to perform further processing or create visualization. It’s been used for qualitative research, social media conversation analysis, legal document review, digital humanities, and more. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e \u003cdiv\u003e\u003cspan\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/div\u003e \u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eOverview can be run via the web interface (max 200 000 documents) or downloaded and installed. \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe system can import documents in PDF or CSV format and currently supports analysis in 9 languages. The code is open source and there is a plugin API to extend Overview's analysis and visualization capability.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/451.jpg","creators_name":"Jonathan Stray, Jonas Karlsson and Adam Hooper","creators_email":"","creators_url":"http://overview.ap.org/team/","star_average":0.0,"url":"https://www.overviewproject.org/","last_updated":"2018-10-19","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/451-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail:
Overview is a free, web-based tool for document mining. Developed by and for journalists, Overview is also broadly applicable to other corpus-based research applications. Aside from providing advanced search features such as regular expressions and fuzzy matching, Overview automatically sorts documents according to topic and provides a fast visualization and reading interface. You can apply tags to search results, individual documents, or entire topics to track what you've found, then export the entire document set with its tags to perform further processing or create visualization. It’s been used for qualitative research, social media conversation analysis, legal document review, digital humanities, and more.    
Overview can be run via the web interface (max 200 000 documents) or downloaded and installed. The system can import documents in PDF or CSV format and currently supports analysis in 9 languages. The code is open source and there is a plugin API to extend Overview's analysis and visualization capability.
name: Overview

RAW uses the D3.js library, and is maintained by the Density Design research studio at Polaitecnico di Milano.

data_tapor: {"id":453,"user_id":null,"name":"SentiStrength","detail":"\u003cp\u003eSentiStrength is a tool for sentiment analysis available for free to academic users (with registration), in Java and Windows-optimized versions. It estimates the strength of sentiment in short texts, and can handle informal language. Strength is expressed in a scale of 1 to 5 for positive sentiments, and -1 to -5 for negative; it also includes an option for assessing neutrality. SentiStrength is available for multiple languages, with extensibility for languages and contexts not already included. According to the developers, SentiStrength has human-level accuracy for short English texts. Commercial users must purchase a license.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/453.jpg","creators_name":"Thelwall, M., Buckley, K., \u0026 Paltoglou, G.; CyberEmotions Consortium","creators_email":"","creators_url":"http://www.cyberemotions.eu/","star_average":0.0,"url":"http://sentistrength.wlv.ac.uk/","last_updated":"2014-07-03","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/453-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: SentiStrength is a tool for sentiment analysis available for free to academic users (with registration), in Java and Windows-optimized versions. It estimates the strength of sentiment in short texts, and can handle informal language. Strength is expressed in a scale of 1 to 5 for positive sentiments, and -1 to -5 for negative; it also includes an option for assessing neutrality. SentiStrength is available for multiple languages, with extensibility for languages and contexts not already included. According to the developers, SentiStrength has human-level accuracy for short English texts. Commercial users must purchase a license.
name: SentiStrength

data_tapor: {"id":459,"user_id":null,"name":"Googlescraper (Lippmannian Device)","detail":"\u003cp\u003eGooglescraper (Lippmannian Device) is a free, web-based tool for querying Google and saving the results for analysis. The tool must be used with FireFox, and requires users to first install the \u003ca href=\"https://wiki.digitalmethods.net/Dmi/FirefoxToolBar\"\u003eDMI toolbar\u003c/a\u003e, which permits the tool to work around Google's block against automated requests.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/459.jpg","creators_name":"Digital Methods Initiative","creators_email":"","creators_url":"https://www.digitalmethods.net/Digitalmethods/WebHome","star_average":0.0,"url":"https://tools.digitalmethods.net/beta/scrapeGoogle/","last_updated":"2018-10-17","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/459-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: Googlescraper (Lippmannian Device) is a free, web-based tool for querying Google and saving the results for analysis. It allow users to specify URLs, keywords, and which keywords apply to each URL. The tool outputs as HTML, a tag cloud, and a text file. The tool must be used with FireFox, and requires users to first install the DMI toolbar, which permits the tool to work around Google's block against automated requests.

data_tapor: {"id":464,"user_id":null,"name":"Lippmannian Device to Gephi","detail":"\u003cp\u003eThe Lippmannian Device to Gephi is a free, web-based tool for converting the output of the Digital Methods Association's \u003ca href=\"../../?id=459\"\u003eGooglescraper (Lippmannian Device)\u003c/a\u003e tool to a format suitable for Gephi visualization. From a Googlescraper file, it generates a GEXF file with defined nodes and weighted edges based on the queries and URLs in the original file. Once loaded into Gephi, the nodes can be resized to emphasize the most important query/URL combinations.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/464.jpg","creators_name":"Digital Methods Initiative","creators_email":"","creators_url":"https://www.digitalmethods.net/Digitalmethods/WebHome","star_average":0.0,"url":"https://tools.digitalmethods.net/beta/lippmannianDeviceToGephi/","last_updated":"2018-10-03","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/464-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: The Lippmannian Device to Gephi is a free, web-based tool for converting the output of the Digital Methods Association's Googlescraper (Lippmannian Device) tool to a format suitable for Gephi visualization. From a Googlescraper file, it generates a GEXF file with defined nodes and weighted edges based on the queries and URLs in the original file. Once loaded into Gephi, the nodes can be resized to emphasize the most important query/URL combinations.
name: Lippmannian Device to Gephi

data_tapor: {"id":467,"user_id":null,"name":"Netlytic","detail":"\u003cp\u003eNetlytic is a free, web-based tool for analyzing and visualizing text and social network data. It enables users to capture data from sources such as social media, blogs or online forums; identify themes and actors; and generate both chain and personal name networks for further analysis and visualization. Users can import datasets from RSS, cloud storage (Google Drive or Dropbox), Twitter, YouTube, Instagram and a plain text file. Results can be exported in formats accessible to other network analysis tools, such as CSV.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/467.jpg","creators_name":"Dr. Anatoliy Gruzd","creators_email":"netlytic@gmail.com","creators_url":"http://anatoliygruzd.com/","star_average":0.0,"url":"https://netlytic.org/home/","last_updated":"2018-10-17","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/467-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: Netlytic is a free, web-based tool for analyzing and visualizing text and social network data. It enables users to capture data from sources such as social media, blogs or online forums; identify themes and actors; and generate both chain and personal name networks for further analysis and visualization. Users can import datasets from RSS, cloud storage (Google Drive or Dropbox), Twitter, YouTube, Instagram and a plain text file. Results can be exported in formats accessible to other network analysis tools, such as CSV.
name: Netlytic

detail: The Macro-Etymological Analyzer is a free, open-source tool for etymological analysis of plain-text documents. Users can upload their own file, or choose from a list of pre-loaded texts. The tool conducts a frequency analysis and then identifies the language families represented in the text from the list of unique words. It outputs a chart showing the percentage of words belonging to each language family identified, a full list of words with those not in the dictionary clearly marked, and a table outputting the full freqency analysis results.
name: Macro-Etymological Analyzer

data_tapor: {"id":471,"user_id":null,"name":"Prospéro (PROgramme de Sociologie Pragmatique, Expérimentale et Réflexive sur Ordinateur)","detail":"\u003cp\u003eProspéro (PROgramme de Sociologie Pragmatique, Expérimentale et Réflexive sur Ordinateur) is a free text analysis tool aimed at scholars in the Humanities capable of complex analysis on natural language. It permits users to classify and track records or thematic sets within a text or corpus for the purpose of exploration, analysis and comparison. It identifies places in a text that display uncertainty, controversy, criticism, and enables the user to establish rule and meta-rules to separate factual statements from views and interpretations. Prospéro is particularly designed for complex cases composed of large texts containing heterogenous discourse.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/0/471.jpg","creators_name":"Francis Chateauraynaud and Jean-Pierre Charriau (Doxa)","creators_email":"","creators_url":"http://prosperologie.org/?sit=61","star_average":0.0,"url":"http://prosperologie.org/?sit=22","last_updated":"2018-11-07","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/0/471-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
name_tapor-api: Prospéro (PROgramme de Sociologie Pragmatique, Expérimentale et Réflexive sur Ordinateur)
detail: Prospéro (PROgramme de Sociologie Pragmatique, Expérimentale et Réflexive sur Ordinateur) is a free text analysis tool aimed at scholars in the Humanities capable of complex analysis on natural language. It permits users to classify and track records or thematic sets within a text or corpus for the purpose of exploration, analysis and comparison. It identifies places in a text that display uncertainty, controversy, criticism, and enables the user to establish rule and meta-rules to separate factual statements from views and interpretations. Prospéro is particularly designed for complex cases composed of large texts containing heterogenous discourse.
name: Prospéro (PROgramme de Sociologie Pragmatique, Expérimentale et Réflexive sur Ordinateur)

data_tapor: {"id":474,"user_id":null,"name":"wordsimilarity (Word 2 Word)","detail":"\u003cp\u003ewordsimilarity (Word 2 Word) is a free, open source tool for plotting and visualizing semantic spaces within a corpus. detail: wordsimilarity (Word 2 Word) is a free, open source tool for plotting and visualizing semantic spaces within a corpus. The tool's visualizations assign words to nodes, with similarities marked by edges between nodes of varying strength. The visualizations are designed to be easy to manipulate based on graph data, and the system includes a library of ready-to-use relationship models with an interface for training the models based on a variety of language sources.
name: wordsimilarity (Word 2 Word)

detail: jsLDA is a free, open source tool for corpus-based in browser topic modelling. Users can test the tool via the provided demo, or download the source code to run on their own system. Users can load any corpus accessible from a URL, and can train the tool on the topics within the corpus via the iteration function. Once jsLDA has been trained to the user's satisfaction, documents can be sorted according to topic and explored based on topic correlations.

detail: NodeXL is a free, open source tool for generating and exploring network graphs from Microsoft Excel files. It is particularly suited to data from social media sources, and includes the ability to directly import data from Twitter, YouTube, Flickr and email, with additional plugins available for gathering data from Facebook, Microsoft Exchange, wikis and URLs. The tool generates visualizations that can be adjusted, zoomed and filtered, with additional features for vertex grouping, graphing metric calculations, and automating tasks. NodeXL can both import and export data in GraphML, Pajek, UCINet and matrix formats.
name: NodeXL

detail: FORTRAN (from 'formula translating system') was a major programming language first developed by IBM in the late 1950s. While originally intended for science and engineering, with substantial drawbacks for users seeking to conduct text processing, its wide availability in academic computing centres neverthless made it an attractive choice for Humanities scholars seeking to automate research processes.

data_tapor: {"id":500,"user_id":1,"name":"Umigon","detail":"\u003cp\u003eUmigon is a tool used for the sentiment analysis of texts. It is one of the tools of the \u003ca href=\"http://tapor.ca/tools/1668\"\u003eNocode app\u003c/a\u003e which is a suite of text analysis tools. Results can be exported in Excel or CSV format for further analysis.\u003c/p\u003e  \u003cp\u003eIt was formerly a stand alone  web-based and open-source tool for the sentiment analysis of tweets. From a person's Twitter handle, Umigon retrieved that account's tweets and processed them for sentiment while accounting for factual statements (ex: \"I hate war\" will be classified has negative, and \"war in Syria\" will be classified as neutral). Tweets could also be pasted manually in the entry box provided. Beyond sentiment analysis, Umigon could identify characteristics such as whether the tweet contains a question, whether it contains possible promotional/commercial subject matter, or temporal indicators based on tense.\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eThe developer of this application can be reached on \u003ca href=\"http://twitter.com/seinecle\"\u003eTwitter.\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cbr\u003eAs of April 2022, Umigon has been archived after a long period without new developments.","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/1/500.jpg","creators_name":"Clement Levallois","creators_email":"levallois@em-lyon.com","creators_url":"http://www.clementlevallois.net","star_average":0.0,"url":"","last_updated":"2022-06-20","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/1/500-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail:
Umigon is a tool used for the sentiment analysis of texts. It is one of the tools of the Nocode app which is a suite of text analysis tools. Results can be exported in Excel or CSV format for further analysis.  It was formerly a stand alone  web-based and open-source tool for the sentiment analysis of tweets. From a person's Twitter handle, Umigon retrieved that account's tweets and processed them for sentiment while accounting for factual statements (ex: "I hate war" will be classified has negative, and "war in Syria" will be classified as neutral). Tweets could also be pasted manually in the entry box provided. Beyond sentiment analysis, Umigon could identify characteristics such as whether the tweet contains a question, whether it contains possible promotional/commercial subject matter, or temporal indicators based on tense. The developer of this application can be reached on Twitter.
As of April 2022, Umigon has been archived after a long period without new developments.
name: Umigon

data_tapor: {"id":506,"user_id":null,"name":"CheckText","detail":"\u003cp\u003eCheckText is a free, web-based text analysis tool. Users can paste in text, upload it from their files, or import content from a web page. For each text, CheckText generates statistics such as word count, syllable count or number of complex words, provides a reading ease and level breakdown, and graphs the most frequent words. The tool also offers a uniqueness check aimed at detecting plagiarism, and generates a PDF report containing the full text with the statistical and readability data.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/1/506.jpg","creators_name":"Northstone Ltd.","creators_email":"info@checktext.org","creators_url":"http://www.northstone.us/","star_average":5.0,"url":"http://www.checktext.org/","last_updated":"2014-09-29","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/1/506-thumb.jpg","rating_count":1,"recipes":""}
detail: CheckText is a free, web-based text analysis tool. Users can paste in text, upload it from their files, or import content from a web page. For each text, CheckText generates statistics such as word count, syllable count or number of complex words, provides a reading ease and level breakdown, and graphs the most frequent words. The tool also offers a uniqueness check aimed at detecting plagiarism, and generates a PDF report containing the full text with the statistical and readability data.
name: CheckText

data_tapor: {"id":507,"user_id":null,"name":"Discursis","detail":"\u003cp\u003eDiscursis is a tool for analyzing text-based natural language with a focus on sequential analysis. It is particularly desgined to work with texts that have an internal temporal structure, such as a transcribed conversation. For each text, it generates a statistics-based internal language model and applies tagging to each temporal unit detected. The model and tagging are then used as the basis for an interactive visualization which permits examination at a various levels of granularity, ranging from a whole-text to a unit-by-unit level; it can also show topic usage patterns within the text. Users must purchase a license; both student and academic trial licenses are available.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/1/507.jpg","creators_name":"Daniel Angus, Andrew Smith and Janet Wiles (University of Queensland)","creators_email":"tom@tombrunoli.com","creators_url":"http://www.discursis.com/index.php/about/","star_average":0.0,"url":"http://www.discursis.com/","last_updated":"2018-10-02","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/1/507-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: Discursis is a tool for analyzing text-based natural language with a focus on sequential analysis. It is particularly desgined to work with texts that have an internal temporal structure, such as a transcribed conversation. For each text, it generates a statistics-based internal language model and applies tagging to each temporal unit detected. The model and tagging are then used as the basis for an interactive visualization which permits examination at a various levels of granularity, ranging from a whole-text to a unit-by-unit level; it can also show topic usage patterns within the text. Users must purchase a license; both student and academic trial licenses are available.
name: Discursis

In addiiton, over 30 graphic types are supported, such as histograms, box plots, scatter plots and normal probability plots. This tool is currently available in Unix, Linux, OS X and Windows versions. Dataplot is open source, but is trademarked rather than licensed.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/1/512.jpg","creators_name":"Alan Heckert and Jim Filliben, National Institute of Standards and Technology","creators_email":"","creators_url":"http://www.itl.nist.gov/div898/","star_average":0.0,"url":"http://www.itl.nist.gov/div898/software/dataplot/homepage.htm","last_updated":"2018-10-05","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/1/512-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: Dataplot is a free software system for data analysis, including characterization, visualization and modelling. It was developed in FORTRAN 77, and has been in continuous development since 1978. Dataplot is well-documented, with numerous tutorials for using and extending it. In addiiton, over 30 graphic types are supported, such as histograms, box plots, scatter plots and normal probability plots. This tool is currently available in Unix, Linux, OS X and Windows versions. Dataplot is open source, but is trademarked rather than licensed.

data_tapor: {"id":513,"user_id":1,"name":"Coggle","detail":"\u003cp\u003eCoggle is a web-based tool for visualizing and applying non-linear structuring to information. Though Coggle has been used for mind mapping, it is primarily a method of documenting branching and non-linear information, and encompassing multiple perspectives. It utlizes a drag and drop interface for integrating images, permits multiple users to edit at the same time without causing data conflicts, and supports Markdown and LaTeX formatting. Coggle diagrams can be interlinked, branches of one diagram can be spawned off into its own diagram connected back to the original, and individual branches can be linked via hashtags. The tool includes an API that permits users to interface their diagrams with other programs and manupulate or examine them, and diagrams can also be exported in various formats such as plain-text outline, vector PDFs or images. Coggle is free except where users require more than 100 monthly active users or a closed source version.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/1/513.jpg","creators_name":"Coggle","creators_email":"","creators_url":"http://coggle.it","star_average":0.0,"url":"http://coggle.it/","last_updated":"2018-10-05","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/1/513-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: Coggle is a web-based tool for visualizing and applying non-linear structuring to information. Though Coggle has been used for mind mapping, it is primarily a method of documenting branching and non-linear information, and encompassing multiple perspectives. It utlizes a drag and drop interface for integrating images, permits multiple users to edit at the same time without causing data conflicts, and supports Markdown and LaTeX formatting. Coggle diagrams can be interlinked, branches of one diagram can be spawned off into its own diagram connected back to the original, and individual branches can be linked via hashtags. The tool includes an API that permits users to interface their diagrams with other programs and manupulate or examine them, and diagrams can also be exported in various formats such as plain-text outline, vector PDFs or images. Coggle is free except where users require more than 100 monthly active users or a closed source version.
name: Coggle

CoCoCo utilizes Ruby on Rails, and is available under an Open Source version 3.0 license.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/1/514.jpg","creators_name":"RunCoCo Project, University of Oxford","creators_email":"runcoco@it.ox.ac.uk","creators_url":"http://projects.oucs.ox.ac.uk/runcoco/index.html","star_average":0.0,"url":"http://projects.oucs.ox.ac.uk/runcoco/index.html","last_updated":"2018-10-30","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/1/514-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: Community Contributed Collection (CoCoCo) is web software developed by the RunCoCo Project at the University of Oxford for collecting, cataloguing and managing web content such as text or uploaded files contributed by a community of users. It enables administrators to assess contributions for quality, approve project-appropriate contributions, and apply metadata where required. Once a contribution is approved, it is available for searching and browsing through the provided interface. CoCoCo utilizes Ruby on Rails, and is available under an Open Source version 3.0 license.
name: Community Contributed Collection (CoCoCo)

detail: Visual Understanding Environment (VUE) is a free, open source application for mapping concepts, ideas and digital content. It enables users to generate nodes and links, and apply a simple set of tools to explore the relationships. VUE is, in the words of its developers, an application to "integrate, organize and contextualize electronic content" in research or learning environments. Its tools include visualization, dynamic content mapping, semantic mapping, enhanced pathways and search functions.
name: Visual Understanding Environment

data_tapor: {"id":519,"user_id":1,"name":"Qualrus","detail":"\u003cp\u003eQualrus is a commercial application for qualitative data analysis, including data coding and statistics functions. In terms of analysis, it offers a number of common text analysis functions including tokenization, co-occurences, and Boolean search, and can visualize a network view of interrelationships. detail: Qualrus is a commercial application for qualitative data analysis, including data coding and statistics functions. It can analyze data from a wide variety of sources, including common text, web, image, video and audio files. The data coding functions are supplemented by machine learning processes to assist data processing and analysis. In terms of analysis, it offers a number of common text analysis functions including tokenization, co-occurences, and Boolean search, and can visualize a network view of interrelationships. It is particularly aimed at academic and institutional applications, and both student and free trial versions are avaiable.

data_tapor: {"id":520,"user_id":1,"name":"ANTHROPAC","detail":"\u003cp\u003eANTHROPAC, now in version 4.98, is a long-standing menu-driven DOS program developed for working with anthropological and other cultural data. It assists both the collection and analysis of datasets, and can accommodate both qualitiative and quantitative information. ANTHROPAC includes analytic tools such as consensus analysis, factor analysis, cluster analysis and correspondance analysis, in addition to data manipulation and transformation functions. It imports and exports data via ASCII formats, and includes an extensive reference manual, a user's guide and a methods guide tailored for cultural domain analysis.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/1/520.jpg","creators_name":"Analytic Technologies","creators_email":"","creators_url":"http://www.analytictech.com/extras/index.htm","star_average":0.0,"url":"http://www.analytictech.com/anthropac/apacdesc.htm","last_updated":"2018-10-17","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/1/520-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: ANTHROPAC, now in version 4.98, is a long-standing menu-driven DOS program developed for working with anthropological and other cultural data. It assists both the collection and analysis of datasets, and can accommodate both qualitiative and quantitative information. ANTHROPAC includes analytic tools such as consensus analysis, factor analysis, cluster analysis and correspondance analysis, in addition to data manipulation and transformation functions. It imports and exports data via ASCII formats, and includes an extensive reference manual, a user's guide and a methods guide tailored for cultural domain analysis.
name: ANTHROPAC

data_tapor: {"id":521,"user_id":1,"name":"SwiftRiver","detail":"\u003cp\u003eSwiftRiver is a free, open source platform for filtering and processing large amounts of information. In particular, it can gather and filter data from common web sources such as email, Twitter or RSS. It also enables users to define 'buckets' according to their own criteria rather than relying on, for example, the information's social media popularity status. Utilizing a combination of filters and buckets, users create 'rivers' of data populated by their chosen sources. Developer Ushahidi has made all code available for general access via Github, though a custom, full-service, hosted version is available for a fee by contacting the company directly.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/1/521.jpg","creators_name":"Ushahidi","creators_email":"","creators_url":"http://www.ushahidi.com/","star_average":0.0,"url":"","last_updated":"2018-10-18","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/1/521-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: SwiftRiver is a free, open source platform for filtering and processing large amounts of information. In particular, it can gather and filter data from common web sources such as email, Twitter or RSS. It also enables users to define 'buckets' according to their own criteria rather than relying on, for example, the information's social media popularity status. Utilizing a combination of filters and buckets, users create 'rivers' of data populated by their chosen sources. Developer Ushahidi has made all code available for general access via Github, though a custom, full-service, hosted version is available for a fee by contacting the company directly.
name: SwiftRiver

data_tapor: {"id":522,"user_id":null,"name":"Siena (Simulation Investigation for Empirical Network Analysis)","detail":"\u003cp\u003eSiena (Simulation Investigation for Empirical Network Analysis) is a free program for statistical analysis developed particularly to work with social network data, but also applicable to other forms of network data. It models network dynamics via Markov chain models; this approach is best applied to data where relations between actors and their behaviour can be treated as a state rather than as an event. Siena's statistical analysis processes can be time-consuming, as the system works via computer simulation of the network. It was in continuous development from 2001 through 2010, releasing versions up to 3.2. Development on Siena as a stand-alone program has concuded, and the project has shifted focus to RSiena, a version of Siena deployed in R.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/1/522.jpg","creators_name":"Tom A.B. Snijders","creators_email":"","creators_url":"http://www.stats.ox.ac.uk/~snijders/","star_average":0.0,"url":"http://www.stats.ox.ac.uk/~snijders/siena/","last_updated":"2014-11-18","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/1/522-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
name_tapor-api: Siena (Simulation Investigation for Empirical Network Analysis)
detail: Siena (Simulation Investigation for Empirical Network Analysis) is a free program for statistical analysis developed particularly to work with social network data, but also applicable to other forms of network data. It models network dynamics via Markov chain models; this approach is best applied to data where relations between actors and their behaviour can be treated as a state rather than as an event. Siena's statistical analysis processes can be time-consuming, as the system works via computer simulation of the network. It was in continuous development from 2001 through 2010, releasing versions up to 3.2. Development on Siena as a stand-alone program has concuded, and the project has shifted focus to RSiena, a version of Siena deployed in R.
name: Siena (Simulation Investigation for Empirical Network Analysis)

data_tapor: {"id":523,"user_id":1,"name":"RSiena","detail":"\u003cp\u003eRSiena is a free, open source social network analysis package for R. It replaces Siena \u003cspan\u003e(Simulation Investigation for Empirical Network Analysis), which was a stand-alone program for Windows. Like its predecessor, RSiena is optimized for social network data, but is also applicable to other forms of network data, and relies on Markov chain models to generate network dynamics. T\u003cspan\u003e\u003cspan\u003ehis approach is best applied to data where relations between actors and their behaviour can be treated as a state rather than as an event. Users not familiar with R can run RSiena via the provided graphical user interface.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/1/523.jpg","creators_name":"Tom A.B. Snijders","creators_email":"","creators_url":"http://www.stats.ox.ac.uk/~snijders/","star_average":0.0,"url":"http://www.stats.ox.ac.uk/~snijders/siena/siena_r.htm","last_updated":"2014-11-18","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/1/523-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: RSiena is a free, open source social network analysis package for R. It replaces Siena (Simulation Investigation for Empirical Network Analysis), which was a stand-alone program for Windows. Like its predecessor, RSiena is optimized for social network data, but is also applicable to other forms of network data, and relies on Markov chain models to generate network dynamics. This approach is best applied to data where relations between actors and their behaviour can be treated as a state rather than as an event. Users not familiar with R can run RSiena via the provided graphical user interface.
name: RSiena

detail: Carrot2 is a free, open source search clustering engine with additional document categorization functions. For each set of search terms, Carrot2 provides a topic tree and subtopics built from the search results, and generates visualizations that enable users to quickly overview their search. Searches can be filtered according to source, such as Bing, image files or the Wikipedia, results can be clustered according to several presets such as K-means or URL, or filtered by country and langauge. It uses Wikipedia for conceptual information, and can also include Google Image search results where applicable. data_tapor: {"id":529,"user_id":null,"name":"ContaWords","detail":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan\u003eWith \u003c/span\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eContaWords\u003c/strong\u003e\u003cspan\u003e you can quickly and easily get a frequency analysis of your texts (pdf, html, txt). The results can be downloaded and easily handled.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eWhen you give \u003cstrong\u003eContaWords\u003c/strong\u003e a task, it first reads the words of a text file and decides what part of speech to assign to each word (credit-Noun-credit but credit-Verb-to_credit). It then begins to count how many times a word appears in the text in every possible way (credits, credit, credited… etc).\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eContaWords\u003c/strong\u003e can also take into account that a sequence of words can, for example, be the name of an organization, a person or an entity (Named Entity Recognition).\u003c/p\u003e \u003cp\u003eBesides all this, \u003cstrong\u003eContaWords\u003c/strong\u003e can find sequences of two words that seem to appear together more often than would be expected, such as \"monetary policy \" or \"fiscal balance \".\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":false,"image_url":"images/tools/1/529.jpg","creators_name":"IULA-UPF CLARIN Competence Center","creators_email":"iulatrl@upf.edu","creators_url":"http://www.clarin-es-lab.org/index-en.html","star_average":5.0,"url":"http://contawords.iula.upf.edu/","last_updated":"2014-11-26","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/1/529-thumb.jpg","rating_count":1,"recipes":""}
detail: With ContaWords you can quickly and easily get a frequency analysis of your texts (pdf, html, txt). The results can be downloaded and easily handled. When you give ContaWords a task, it first reads the words of a text file and decides what part of speech to assign to each word (credit-Noun-credit but credit-Verb-to_credit). It then begins to count how many times a word appears in the text in every possible way (credits, credit, credited… etc). ContaWords can also take into account that a sequence of words can, for example, be the name of an organization, a person or an entity (Named Entity Recognition). Besides all this, ContaWords can find sequences of two words that seem to appear together more often than would be expected, such as "monetary policy " or "fiscal balance ".
name: ContaWords

data_tapor: {"id":530,"user_id":null,"name":"Alveo","detail":"\u003cp\u003eAlveo is a platform for data discovery and analysis focused on communication data such as speech, text or video. Developed by the University of Western Sydney, researchers can use the Alveo infrastructure to store data, create collections, develop workflows, and analyze datasets with Alveo's built-in tools. The tools available span multiple disciplines and include common functions such as tokenization and concordance, plus interfaces between Alveo and other common analysis tools such as Apache's UIMA for NLP, and with programming languages such as Python and Java. Users can segmented and recombined data from multiple collections into a new, focused dataset for close analysis. Collection creators can set their own license and access rights, and users of a collection must accept the creator's conditions in order to use data from it. User accounts are free, but must be requested from and approved by Alveo.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/1/530.jpg","creators_name":"Steve Cassidy, Dominique Estival, Tim Jones, Denis Burnham and Jared Berghold (University of Western Sydney)","creators_email":"","creators_url":"http://alveo.edu.au/","star_average":0.0,"url":"http://alveo.edu.au/","last_updated":"2018-10-12","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/1/530-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: Alveo is a platform for data discovery and analysis focused on communication data such as speech, text or video. Developed by the University of Western Sydney, researchers can use the Alveo infrastructure to store data, create collections, develop workflows, and analyze datasets with Alveo's built-in tools. The tools available span multiple disciplines and include common functions such as tokenization and concordance, plus interfaces between Alveo and other common analysis tools such as Apache's UIMA for NLP, and with programming languages such as Python and Java. Users can segmented and recombined data from multiple collections into a new, focused dataset for close analysis. Collection creators can set their own license and access rights, and users of a collection must accept the creator's conditions in order to use data from it. User accounts are free, but must be requested from and approved by Alveo.
name: Alveo

Using SPARQL to access the user's dataset, it arranges RDF data into a scatter plot which can be analyzed via semantic lenses generated based on the dataset, and with logical operators. The tool provides a global overview of the user's dataset, and can do so even for large datasets.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/1/532.jpg","creators_name":"DEI Interactive Systems Group","creators_email":"contact@visualdataweb.org","creators_url":"http://www.visualdataweb.org/people.php","star_average":0.0,"url":"http://www.visualdataweb.org/semlens.php","last_updated":"2018-10-26","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/1/532-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: SemLens is a tool for visualizing and analyzing RDF data developed as part of the Visual Data Web toolset and based on the Adobe Flex open source framework. Using SPARQL to access the user's dataset, it arranges RDF data into a scatter plot which can be analyzed via semantic lenses generated based on the dataset, and with logical operators. The tool provides a global overview of the user's dataset, and can do so even for large datasets.
name: SemLens

Using SPARQL to access the user's dataset, it integrates filtering based on facets represented as nodes within the visualization to enable users to select which they wish to work with and create custom search interfaces. \u003cbr\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/1/533.jpg","creators_name":"DEI Interactive Systems Group","creators_email":"contact@visualdataweb.org","creators_url":"http://www.visualdataweb.org/people.php","star_average":0.0,"url":"http://www.visualdataweb.org/gfacet.php","last_updated":"2018-09-18","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/1/533-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: gFacet is a tool for graph-based visualization of RDF data developed as part of the Visual Data Web toolset and based on the Adobe Flex open source framework. Using SPARQL to access the user's dataset, it integrates filtering based on facets represented as nodes within the visualization to enable users to select which they wish to work with and create custom search interfaces.
name: gFacet

data_tapor: {"id":534,"user_id":null,"name":"tFacet","detail":"tFacet applies known interaction concepts to allow hierarchical faceted exploration of RDF data. The aim is to facilitate ordinary users to formulate semantically unambiguous queries so as to support the fast and precise access to information. Used interaction concepts are e.g. a directory tree and interchangeable columns that are already well-known from other applications. The directory tree, for example, is used to enable the intuitive exploration and selection of hierarchical facets. tFacet is based on the open source framework Adobe Flex and uses SPARQL to access RDF datasets.","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/1/534.jpg","creators_name":"DEI Interactive Systems Group","creators_email":"contact@visualdataweb.org","creators_url":"http://www.visualdataweb.org/people.php","star_average":0.0,"url":"http://www.visualdataweb.org/tfacet.php","last_updated":"2018-10-26","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/1/534-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: tFacet applies known interaction concepts to allow hierarchical faceted exploration of RDF data. The aim is to facilitate ordinary users to formulate semantically unambiguous queries so as to support the fast and precise access to information. Used interaction concepts are e.g. a directory tree and interchangeable columns that are already well-known from other applications. The directory tree, for example, is used to enable the intuitive exploration and selection of hierarchical facets. tFacet is based on the open source framework Adobe Flex and uses SPARQL to access RDF datasets.
name: tFacet

detail: minezy is a prototype application for exploring and mining large email archives. Its interface is designed to make it easy to find the answers to common questions: who the message originator was, when messages were sent, how frequently, who was included in the exchange, and the subject and content. The app interface is designed around search, filters and a series of panels that open to the right when results and sub-results are clicked on. The prototype can be tried out via the minezy website, and is pre-loaded with the Enron collection of emails for exploration.
name: minezy

detail:
A very simple/specialized piece of Java code that takes a csv file produced by "Youtube Comment Scraper" - http://ytcomments.klostermann.ca/ and collapses the replies down into the same categories that basic comments are under. This makes it easier to compare all comments to each other.

NOTE: The name of the csv file to be parsed has to be written into the code, assigned to the variable "inFile".
name: Youtube Scraper CSV Cleaner
