data_tapor:
{"id":1542,"user_id":1149,"name":"TerraME","detail":"TerraME is a programming environment for spatial dynamical modelling. It supports cellular automata, agent-based models, and network models running in 2D cell spaces. TerraME provides an interface to TerraLib geographical database, allowing models direct access to geospatial data. Its modelling language has in-built functions that makes it easier to develop multi-scale and multi-paradigm models for environmental applications.

Two important innovations in TerraME are its use of anisotropic spaces and of hybrid automata models. Anisotropic spaces arise when modeling natural and human-related phenomena. For example, land settlers in a new area do not occupy all places at the same time. They follow roads and rivers, leading to an anisotropic pattern. Anisotropic spaces are implemented in TerraME using Generalized Proximity Matrices (GPM). The GPM is an extension of the usual definition of the spatial relations and include a combination of neighborhood measures in the absolute space and in the relative space.

A hybrid automaton is an abstract model for a system whose behavior has discrete and continuous parts. It extends the idea of finite automata to allow continuous change to take place between transitions. Adopting hybrid automata in spatial dynamical models allows complex models which include critical transitions.

","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/3/1542.jpg","creators_name":"Earth System Science Center (CCST/INPE), TerraLab (Laboratory for Modelling and Simulation of Earth Systems), at Federal University of Ouro Preto, and Image Processing Division (DPI/INPE)","creators_email":"","creators_url":"","star_average":0.0,"url":"http://www.terrame.org/doku.php","last_updated":"2018-12-13","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"https://github.com/TerraME/terrame","thumb_url":"images/tools/3/1542-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail:
TerraME is a programming environment for spatial dynamical modelling. It supports cellular automata, agent-based models, and network models running in 2D cell spaces. TerraME provides an interface to TerraLib geographical database, allowing models direct access to geospatial data. Its modelling language has in-built functions that makes it easier to develop multi-scale and multi-paradigm models for environmental applications.

Two important innovations in TerraME are its use of anisotropic spaces and of hybrid automata models. Anisotropic spaces arise when modeling natural and human-related phenomena. For example, land settlers in a new area do not occupy all places at the same time. They follow roads and rivers, leading to an anisotropic pattern. Anisotropic spaces are implemented in TerraME using Generalized Proximity Matrices (GPM). The GPM is an extension of the usual definition of the spatial relations and include a combination of neighborhood measures in the absolute space and in the relative space.

A hybrid automaton is an abstract model for a system whose behavior has discrete and continuous parts. It extends the idea of finite automata to allow continuous change to take place between transitions. Adopting hybrid automata in spatial dynamical models allows complex models which include critical transitions.
name: TerraME

data_tapor: {"id":1543,"user_id":1149,"name":"SSELab","detail":"The SSELab is an extensible platform for the development and application of software engineering techniques and concepts.\n\u003cp\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\u003cp\u003e\nThe SSELab provides basic project hosting services such as a version control system and a project management and bug-tracking tool as well as advanced software engineering services such as code generators for model-based software engineering.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/3/1543.jpg","creators_name":"Software Engineering - RWTH Aachen University","creators_email":"","creators_url":"","star_average":0.0,"url":"https://sselab.de/lab1/","last_updated":"2018-12-13","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/3/1543-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail:
The SSELab is an extensible platform for the development and application of software engineering techniques and concepts.

The SSELab provides basic project hosting services such as a version control system and a project management and bug-tracking tool as well as advanced software engineering services such as code generators for model-based software engineering.
name: SSELab

data_tapor:
{"id":1544,"user_id":1149,"name":"Code Bubbles","detail":"Code Bubbles is a front end to Eclipse designed to simplify programming by making it easy for the programmer to define and use working sets. Working sets here consist of the group of functions, documentation, notes, and other information that a programmer needs to accomplish a particular programming task such as adding a feature or fixing a bug.

Code Bubbles accomplishes this by providing compact function-based views of the code (all backed by the underlying files) that are displayed in bubbles and that are easily moved around and manipulated on the screen. The bubbles are fully editable. A large bubble area lets the programmer set up different working sets simultaneously and easily move between them.

In addition to providing facilities for editing and understanding code, the Code Bubbles front end provides facilities for debugging and testing programs.

","is_approved":false,"image_url":"images/tools/3/1544.jpg","creators_name":"Steve Reiss","creators_email":"spr@cs.brown.edu","creators_url":"","star_average":0.0,"url":"http://cs.brown.edu/~spr/codebubbles/","last_updated":"2018-12-13","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/3/1544-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail:
Code Bubbles is a front end to Eclipse designed to simplify programming by making it easy for the programmer to define and use working sets. Working sets here consist of the group of functions, documentation, notes, and other information that a programmer needs to accomplish a particular programming task such as adding a feature or fixing a bug.

Code Bubbles accomplishes this by providing compact function-based views of the code (all backed by the underlying files) that are displayed in bubbles and that are easily moved around and manipulated on the screen. The bubbles are fully editable. A large bubble area lets the programmer set up different working sets simultaneously and easily move between them.

In addition to providing facilities for editing and understanding code, the Code Bubbles front end provides facilities for debugging and testing programs.
name: Code Bubbles

data_tapor:
{"id":1545,"user_id":1149,"name":"Cinco","detail":"The “CINCO SCCE Meta Tooling Framework” is a generator-driven development environment for domain-specific graphical modeling tools. It is based on the Eclipse Modeling Framework and Graphiti Graphical Tooling Infrastructrure, but aims to hide much of their complexity and intricate APIs.

A graphical modeling tool developed with CINCO is completely generated from an intuitive higher-level abstract specification language. Semantics-inducing parts of the tool that are difficult to define in an abstract declarative way (such as model interpreters, transformations, or code generators) are written in Java against a simple model-based API. CINCO handles the inclusion of the right buttons in the GUI that trigger those actions.

Furthermore, CINCO supports the integration of the Java Application Building Center (jABC) into the development process, so that even people with little or no programming experience can express model behavior in a process-oriented fashion.

","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/3/1545.jpg","creators_name":"SCCE","creators_email":"","creators_url":"https://www.scce.info/","star_average":0.0,"url":"","last_updated":"2018-12-13","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/3/1545-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail:
The “CINCO SCCE Meta Tooling Framework” is a generator-driven development environment for domain-specific graphical modeling tools. It is based on the Eclipse Modeling Framework and Graphiti Graphical Tooling Infrastructrure, but aims to hide much of their complexity and intricate APIs.

A graphical modeling tool developed with CINCO is completely generated from an intuitive higher-level abstract specification language. Semantics-inducing parts of the tool that are difficult to define in an abstract declarative way (such as model interpreters, transformations, or code generators) are written in Java against a simple model-based API. CINCO handles the inclusion of the right buttons in the GUI that trigger those actions.

Furthermore, CINCO supports the integration of the Java Application Building Center (jABC) into the development process, so that even people with little or no programming experience can express model behavior in a process-oriented fashion.
name: Cinco

data_tapor:
{"id":1551,"user_id":1149,"name":"OSoMe","detail":"OSoMe (awe•some) is a joint project of the Indiana University Network Science Institute (IUNI) and the Center for Complex Networks and Systems Research (CNetS), aimed to study information diffusion in social media. Here we highlight findings, publications, and resources. Use our tools to explore how ideas spread through online social networks.

Hoaxy: Visualize the spread of claims and fact checking.

Botometer: Check how bot-like a Twitter user behaves.

Fakey: PLay this game to learn to recognize fake news on your social feed.

Trends: Compare when memes gain and lose popularity.

Networks: Explore who is discussing a meme and what memes are related.

Maps: Examine where people are talking about a meme over time.

Movies: Generate movies of how conversations about a meme evolve over time.

EchoDemo: Simulation demonstrating how two basic mechanisms of social media can lead to polarized social networks.

Bot Electioneering Volume: Visualizing the activity of likely bots on Twitter around the 2018 US midterm elections.

As well as API and Enhanced Data available.","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/3/1551.jpg","creators_name":"Indiana University","creators_email":"truthyatindiana@gmail.com","creators_url":"http://www.indiana.edu/","star_average":0.0,"url":"https://truthy.indiana.edu/","last_updated":"2019-02-27","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/3/1551-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail:
OSoMe (awe•some) is a joint project of the Indiana University Network Science Institute (IUNI) and the Center for Complex Networks and Systems Research (CNetS), aimed to study information diffusion in social media. Here we highlight findings, publications, and resources. Use our tools to explore how ideas spread through online social networks.

Hoaxy: Visualize the spread of claims and fact checking.

Botometer: Check how bot-like a Twitter user behaves.

Fakey: PLay this game to learn to recognize fake news on your social feed.

Trends: Compare when memes gain and lose popularity.

Networks: Explore who is discussing a meme and what memes are related.

Maps: Examine where people are talking about a meme over time.

Movies: Generate movies of how conversations about a meme evolve over time.

EchoDemo: Simulation demonstrating how two basic mechanisms of social media can lead to polarized social networks.

Bot Electioneering Volume: Visualizing the activity of likely bots on Twitter around the 2018 US midterm elections.

As well as API and Enhanced Data available.
name: OSoMe

data_tapor: {"id":1553,"user_id":1149,"name":"ASV Online Toolbox","detail":"ASV Toolbox is a modular collection of tools for the exploration of written language data. They work either on word lists or text and solve several linguistic classification and clustering tasks. The topics covered contain language detection, POS-tagging, base form reduction, named entity recognition, and terminology extraction. On a more abstract level, the algorithms deal with various kinds of word similarity, using pattern based and statistical approaches. The collection can be used to work on large real world data sets as well as for studying the underlying algorithms.","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/3/1553.jpg","creators_name":"Leipzig University","creators_email":"","creators_url":"https://www.uni-leipzig.de/en/","star_average":0.0,"url":"https://toolbox.wortschatz.uni-leipzig.de/toolbox/","last_updated":"2019-03-14","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/3/1553-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: ASV Toolbox is a modular collection of tools for the exploration of written language data. They work either on word lists or text and solve several linguistic classification and clustering tasks. The topics covered contain language detection, POS-tagging, base form reduction, named entity recognition, and terminology extraction. On a more abstract level, the algorithms deal with various kinds of word similarity, using pattern based and statistical approaches. The collection can be used to work on large real world data sets as well as for studying the underlying algorithms.
name: ASV Online Toolbox

data_tapor: {"id":1561,"user_id":1150,"name":"TRACER","detail":"TRACER is a suite of 700 algorithms, whose features can be combined to create the optimal formula for detecting those words, sentences and ideas that have been reused across texts. Created by Marco Büchler, TRACER is designed to facilitate research in text reuse detection and many have made use of it to identify plagiarism in a text, as well as verbatim and near verbatim quotations, paraphrase and even allusions. The thousands of feature combinations that TRACER supports allow to investigate not only contemporary texts, but also complex historical texts where reuse is harder to spot.","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/3/1561.jpg","creators_name":"","creators_email":"","creators_url":"","star_average":0.0,"url":"https://www.etrap.eu/research/tracer/","last_updated":"2019-04-05","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/3/1561-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: TRACER is a suite of 700 algorithms, whose features can be combined to create the optimal formula for detecting those words, sentences and ideas that have been reused across texts. Created by Marco Büchler, TRACER is designed to facilitate research in text reuse detection and many have made use of it to identify plagiarism in a text, as well as verbatim and near verbatim quotations, paraphrase and even allusions. The thousands of feature combinations that TRACER supports allow to investigate not only contemporary texts, but also complex historical texts where reuse is harder to spot.
name: TRACER

SentiStrength was originally developed for English and optimised for general short social web texts but can be configured for other languages and contexts by changing its input files - some variants are demonstrated below.","is_approved":false,"image_url":"images/tools/3/1564.jpg","creators_name":"","creators_email":"","creators_url":"","star_average":0.0,"url":"http://sentistrength.wlv.ac.uk/","last_updated":"2019-09-20","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/3/1564-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}

data_tapor: {"id":1565,"user_id":1201,"name":"SentiStrength","detail":"SentiStrength is a sentiment analysis (opinion mining) program. SentiStrength estimates the strength of positive and negative sentiment in short texts. It is ideal for short texts like tweets.\nThere is an online version and a downloadable Java version which has more options. \nIt is stated to be able to analyse 16,000 tweets per second. To enter multiply short test, each text has to be put on a new line. SentiStrength will give a rating of the positive and negative sentiment strength for each line in a generated text file.","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/3/1565.jpg","creators_name":"Mike Thelwall","creators_email":"m.thelwall@wlv.ac.uk","creators_url":"http://sentistrength.wlv.ac.uk","star_average":0.0,"url":"http://sentistrength.wlv.ac.uk/","last_updated":"2019-11-01","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/3/1565-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail:
SentiStrength is a sentiment analysis (opinion mining) program. SentiStrength estimates the strength of positive and negative sentiment in short texts. It is ideal for short texts like tweets.
There is an online version and a downloadable Java version which has more options. 
It is stated to be able to analyse 16,000 tweets per second. To enter multiply short test, each text has to be put on a new line. SentiStrength will give a rating of the positive and negative sentiment strength for each line in a generated text file.
name: SentiStrength

Just like a Jupyter notebook environment but hosted entirely in the cloud by Google. Python code can be executed without any setup or installation on your computer.\nIts outputs are not limited to text for it can produce very rich interactive visualisations with the many visualisation libraries it supports. Notebooks are easily shared in Google drive and Github. It has links to a bank of shared code and tutorials. With Colab the code are run on Google servers which usually offer better processing power than personal computer.","is_approved":false,"image_url":"images/tools/3/1567.jpg","creators_name":"Google","creators_email":"","creators_url":"https://colab.research.google.com","star_average":0.0,"url":"Colab.research.google.com","last_updated":"2021-03-26","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/3/1567-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail:
Google Colab is an online platform hosted by Google to write, run and share code. Just like a Jupyter notebook environment but hosted entirely in the cloud by Google. Python code can be executed without any setup or installation on your computer.
Its outputs are not limited to text for it can produce very rich interactive visualisations with the many visualisation libraries it supports. Notebooks are easily shared in Google drive and Github. It has links to a bank of shared code and tutorials. With Colab the code are run on Google servers which usually offer better processing power than personal computer.
name: Google Colab

These two files are read with VosViewer to produce a map of the most frequent words, arranged according to how frequently they are connected in the same text","is_approved":false,"image_url":"images/tools/3/1569.jpg","creators_name":"Clement Levallois","creators_email":"clementlevallois@gmail.com","creators_url":"http://www.clementlevallois.net/portfolio.html","star_average":0.0,"url":"https://github.com/seinecle/Cowo/blob/master/README.md","last_updated":"2019-09-27","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/3/1569-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: Cowo reads a text file, detect frequent words contained in it, and find the connections between these frequent words. Cowo creates several files, two of which are really important (a "map" file and a "network" file). These two files are read with VosViewer to produce a map of the most frequent words, arranged according to how frequently they are connected in the same text
name: Cowo

data_tapor: {"id":1570,"user_id":1201,"name":"CasualConc","detail":"CasualConc is a concordance program that runs natively on macOS 10.11 or later. The current version (2.0 or later) can generate Key Word in Context concordance lines, word clusters, collocation analysis, and word count. This program is only tested with English text just because that is the only language but technically, it should be able to handle any language macOS can. This new version (2.0) has visualization functions using the statistical environment R (needs to be installed separately). It works best with plain text files (.txt) encoded in ASCII or UTF-8, but can handle other file types and other encodings.  Reading non-plain text files will take more time to process. detail: CasualConc is a concordance program that runs natively on macOS 10.11 or later. The current version (2.0 or later) can generate Key Word in Context concordance lines, word clusters, collocation analysis, and word count. This program is only tested with English text just because that is the only language but technically, it should be able to handle any language macOS can. This new version (2.0) has visualization functions using the statistical environment R (needs to be installed separately). It works best with plain text files (.txt) encoded in ASCII or UTF-8, but can handle other file types and other encodings.  Reading non-plain text files will take more time to process.  PDF files should be text-embedded.
name: CasualConc

{"id":1577,"user_id":1201,"name":"CATMA 6.0","detail":"CATMA 6.0 is a free online tool that helps you to annotate, interpret, analyze and visualize text.  CATMA stands for Computer Assisted Text Markup and Analysis. It is an update from CATMA 5. With CATMA 6.0 you can:

There are word clouds, graphs and networks visualizations.","is_approved":false,"image_url":"images/tools/3/1577.jpg","creators_name":"Jan Christoph Meister, Jan Horstmann, Marco Petris, Janina Jacke & Christian Bruck","creators_email":"jan-c-meister@uni-hamburg.de","creators_url":"https://jcmeister.de/","star_average":0.0,"url":"https://catma.de","last_updated":"2019-11-17","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"https://github.com/mpetris/catma","thumb_url":"images/tools/3/1577-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail:
CATMA 6.0 is a free online tool that helps you to annotate, interpret, analyze and visualize text.  CATMA stands for Computer Assisted Text Markup and Analysis. It is an update from CATMA 5. With CATMA 6.0 you can:
-Upload your own corpus and share it with others to work collaboratively.
-Annotate your texts in an undogmatic fashion. Where required: multiple, overlapping, short, extensive, discontinuous or even in contradictory variants can be used.
-Develop your own tagset or import an existing one.
-Choose from several interactive visualizations for your data. There are word clouds, graphs and networks visualizations.
name: CATMA

data_tapor: {"id":1578,"user_id":1201,"name":"Manifold","detail":"\u003cp\u003eManifold Scholarship is an open-source publishing platform that enables authors and publishers a means to showcase and enhance the electronic content they already produce in their existing workflows: texts are displayed in a responsive, elegant reader crafted for all modern browsers and devices—desktop and mobile. Powerful built-in annotation and commenting systems allow readers to annotate, highlight, discuss, cite, and share passages from any Manifold text. Resources that are foundational to a particular discussion but that are often tabled because of physical, technical, logistic, or legal limitations can be layered dynamically and directly onto the digital text. And with Manifold, a new kind of publication is possible, one where authors create projects that grow iteratively and that are published online as they are created and then later in print, when they have been codified as versions of record. In short, Manifold transforms scholarly publications into living digital works.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/3/1578.jpg","creators_name":"CUNY Graduate Center, University of Minnesota Press, Cast Iron Coding","creators_email":"contact@manifoldapp.org","creators_url":"http://manifoldapp.org/","star_average":0.0,"url":"http://manifoldapp.org/","last_updated":"2019-11-29","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"https://github.com/ManifoldScholar","thumb_url":"images/tools/3/1578-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: Manifold Scholarship is an open-source publishing platform that enables authors and publishers a means to showcase and enhance the electronic content they already produce in their existing workflows: texts are displayed in a responsive, elegant reader crafted for all modern browsers and devices—desktop and mobile. Powerful built-in annotation and commenting systems allow readers to annotate, highlight, discuss, cite, and share passages from any Manifold text. Resources that are foundational to a particular discussion but that are often tabled because of physical, technical, logistic, or legal limitations can be layered dynamically and directly onto the digital text. And with Manifold, a new kind of publication is possible, one where authors create projects that grow iteratively and that are published online as they are created and then later in print, when they have been codified as versions of record. In short, Manifold transforms scholarly publications into living digital works.
name: Manifold

data_tapor:
{"id":1580,"user_id":1201,"name":"WebLicht","detail":"WebLicht is an execution environment for automatic annotation of text corpora. Linguistic tools such as tokenizers, part of speech taggers, and parsers are encapsulated as web services, which can be combined by the user into custom processing chains. The resulting annotations can then be visualized in an appropriate way, such as in a table or tree format.
It is often the case that a tool relies on one or more annotation layers to exist in the input data before it can begin processing. WebLicht can assist the user in building a processing chain by determining which tools are able to operate on the data at any given point and offering only those tools as options to add to the chain.

There are 2 modes for building tool chains:
Easy Mode lets you choose pre-defined processing chains
Advanced Mode allows you to build customized tool chains.

Login is required to use the tools and corpora. Login with email addresses from most recognized European universities will be automatically accepted. Individuals with a Non-European email address need to create an account with clarin.eu

Developed by the German language resource infrastructure (D-SPIN) and Common language resources and technology infrastructure (CLARIN)","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/3/1580.jpg","creators_name":"D-SPIN and CLARIN","creators_email":"eh@sfs.uni-tuebingen.de","creators_url":"http://mpiwiki.mpi.nl/DspinWiki, http://www.clarin.eu/","star_average":0.0,"url":"https://weblicht.sfs.uni-tuebingen.de/weblicht/","last_updated":"2019-12-10","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/3/1580-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail:
WebLicht is an execution environment for automatic annotation of text corpora. Linguistic tools such as tokenizers, part of speech taggers, and parsers are encapsulated as web services, which can be combined by the user into custom processing chains. The resulting annotations can then be visualized in an appropriate way, such as in a table or tree format.
It is often the case that a tool relies on one or more annotation layers to exist in the input data before it can begin processing. WebLicht can assist the user in building a processing chain by determining which tools are able to operate on the data at any given point and offering only those tools as options to add to the chain.

There are 2 modes for building tool chains:
Easy Mode lets you choose pre-defined processing chains
Advanced Mode allows you to build customized tool chains.

Login is required to use the tools and corpora. Login with email addresses from most recognized European universities will be automatically accepted. Individuals with a Non-European email address need to create an account with clarin.eu

Developed by the German language resource infrastructure (D-SPIN) and Common language resources and technology infrastructure (CLARIN)
name: WebLicht

{"id":1584,"user_id":1201,"name":"Nerf","detail":"Nerf is a statistical named entity recognition (NER) tool based on linear-chain conditional random fields (CRFs). It has been adapted to recognize tree-like structures of NEs (i.e., with recursively embedded NEs) by using the joined label tagging method which -- for a particular sentence -- works as follows:

CRF model is used to determine the most probable sequence of labels,
Extended IOB method is used to decode the sequence into a forerst of NEs.
The extended IOB method also provides the inverse encoding function which is needed during the model training.","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/3/1584.jpg","creators_name":"Jakub Waszczuk","creators_email":"waszczuk@phil.hhu.de","creators_url":"https://github.com/kawu/nerf","star_average":0.0,"url":"http://zil.ipipan.waw.pl/Nerf","last_updated":"2019-12-11","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"https://github.com/kawu/nerf","thumb_url":"images/tools/3/1584-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail:
Nerf is a statistical named entity recognition (NER) tool based on linear-chain conditional random fields (CRFs). It has been adapted to recognize tree-like structures of NEs (i.e., with recursively embedded NEs) by using the joined label tagging method which -- for a particular sentence -- works as follows:

CRF model is used to determine the most probable sequence of labels,
Extended IOB method is used to decode the sequence into a forerst of NEs.
The extended IOB method also provides the inverse encoding function which is needed during the model training.
name: Nerf

data_tapor: {"id":1585,"user_id":1201,"name":"Concraft-pl 2.0","detail":"Concraft-pl, a morphosyntactic tagger for the Polish language based on conditional random fields. The tool is coupled with Morfeusz, a morphosyntactic analyzer for Polish, which represents both morphosyntactic and segmentation ambiguities in the form of a directed acyclic graph (DAG).\n\nAs for now, the tagger doesn't provide any lemmatisation capabilities. As a result, it may output multiple interpretations (all related to the same morphosyntactic tag, but with different lemmas) for some known words, while for the out-of-vocabulary words it just outputs orthographic forms as lemmas.","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/3/1585.jpg","creators_name":"Jakub Waszczuk","creators_email":"waszczuk@phil.hhu.de","creators_url":"https://github.com/kawu/concraft-pl","star_average":0.0,"url":"http://zil.ipipan.waw.pl/Concraft","last_updated":"2019-12-11","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"https://github.com/kawu/concraft-pl","thumb_url":"images/tools/3/1585-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail:
Concraft-pl, a morphosyntactic tagger for the Polish language based on conditional random fields. The tool is coupled with Morfeusz, a morphosyntactic analyzer for Polish, which represents both morphosyntactic and segmentation ambiguities in the form of a directed acyclic graph (DAG).

As for now, the tagger doesn't provide any lemmatisation capabilities. As a result, it may output multiple interpretations (all related to the same morphosyntactic tag, but with different lemmas) for some known words, while for the out-of-vocabulary words it just outputs orthographic forms as lemmas.
name: Concraft-pl 2.0

data_tapor: {"id":1587,"user_id":1201,"name":"forTEXT","detail":"forTEXT is a free web service, which helps scholars who are interested in the Digital\nHumanities to choose digital methods and tools according to their research setting. forTEXT is especially designed for scholars with no or little experience in the field of Digital Humanities. The focus currently lies on literature studies and language, but will be broadened in the future. forTEXT provides scientific insights into traditions and techniques of the Digital Humanities and offers video and text tutorials as well as teaching materials.\nCurrently, forTEXT offers content in German, but is going to be translated into English and other languages soon.","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/3/1587.jpg","creators_name":"forTEXT Team","creators_email":"info@fortext.net","creators_url":"","star_average":0.0,"url":"https://fortext.net/","last_updated":"2020-01-07","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/3/1587-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail:
forTEXT is a free web service, which helps scholars who are interested in the Digital
Humanities to choose digital methods and tools according to their research setting. forTEXT is especially designed for scholars with no or little experience in the field of Digital Humanities. The focus currently lies on literature studies and language, but will be broadened in the future. forTEXT provides scientific insights into traditions and techniques of the Digital Humanities and offers video and text tutorials as well as teaching materials.
Currently, forTEXT offers content in German, but is going to be translated into English and other languages soon.
name: forTEXT

data_tapor: {"id":1597,"user_id":1201,"name":"Kubity","detail":"Kubity is a cloud-based 3D communication tool that works on desktop computers, the web, smartphones, tablets, augmented reality gear, and virtual reality glasses. Kubity is powered by several proprietary 3D processing engines including \"Paragone\" and \"Etna\" that prepare the 3D file for transfer over mobile devices. 3D images can be uploaded and enhanced and used in an artificial reality environment. It also has augmented reality features. It can be used in architecture, interior design, engineering, product design, film and video games among others. detail: Kubity is a cloud-based 3D communication tool that works on desktop computers, the web, smartphones, tablets, augmented reality gear, and virtual reality glasses. Kubity is powered by several proprietary 3D processing engines including "Paragone" and "Etna" that prepare the 3D file for transfer over mobile devices. 3D images can be uploaded and enhanced and used in an artificial reality environment. It also has augmented reality features. It can be used in architecture, interior design, engineering, product design, film and video games among others. The majority of its users create 3D models using SketchUp or Autodesk Revit software.
name: Kubity

detail:
Bl.ock is a simple viewer for sharing code examples hosted on GitHub Gist. For example, if your Gist URL is:
https://gist.github.com/mbostock/1353700
Replace “gist.github.com” with “bl.ocks.org” in the URL to view it:
https://bl.ocks.org/mbostock/1353700
It has configurations to determine how your block will be displayed. Bl.ock runs your visualization code (usually is d3) and displays it, unlike github that only displays the code.
name: bl.ock

data_tapor: {"id":1603,"user_id":1201,"name":"spaCy","detail":"spaCy is an open-source software library for advanced natural language processing, written in the programming languages Python and Cython. The library is published under the MIT license and currently offers statistical neural network models for English, German, Spanish, Portuguese, French, Italian, Dutch and multi-language NER, as well as tokenization for various other languages.\n\nUnlike NLTK, which is widely used for teaching and research, spaCy focuses on providing software for production usage. As of version 1.0, spaCy also supports deep learning workflows that allow connecting statistical models trained by popular machine learning libraries like TensorFlow, Keras, Scikit-learn or PyTorch. spaCy's machine learning library, Thinc, is also available as a separate open-source Python library. It features convolutional neural network models for part-of-speech tagging, dependency parsing and named entity recognition, as well as API improvements around training and updating models, and constructing custom processing pipelines.","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/3/1603.jpg","creators_name":"Matthew Honnibal","creators_email":"","creators_url":"","star_average":0.0,"url":"https://spacy.io/","last_updated":"2020-02-07","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"https://github.com/explosion/spaCy","thumb_url":"images/tools/3/1603-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail:
spaCy is an open-source software library for advanced natural language processing, written in the programming languages Python and Cython. The library is published under the MIT license and currently offers statistical neural network models for English, German, Spanish, Portuguese, French, Italian, Dutch and multi-language NER, as well as tokenization for various other languages.

Unlike NLTK, which is widely used for teaching and research, spaCy focuses on providing software for production usage. As of version 1.0, spaCy also supports deep learning workflows that allow connecting statistical models trained by popular machine learning libraries like TensorFlow, Keras, Scikit-learn or PyTorch. spaCy's machine learning library, Thinc, is also available as a separate open-source Python library. It features convolutional neural network models for part-of-speech tagging, dependency parsing and named entity recognition, as well as API improvements around training and updating models, and constructing custom processing pipelines.
name: SpaCy

data_tapor: {"id":1604,"user_id":1201,"name":"Intelligent Archive","detail":"Intelligent Archive is a Java application for stylometry, or computational and statistical analysis of style in texts, produced by the University of Newcastle's Centre for Literary and Linguistic Computing (CLLC). It can handle corpora of plain text, HTML, XML and TEI texts. IA enables you to easily organise texts into sets, manage metadata, generate word frequencies, handle XML tags, and split texts in various ways to generate results that can be exported for further analysis in statistical software. It includes some experimental stylometry techniques developed at the CLLC and special features for handling literary texts such as generating word frequencies for speaking characters in plays.","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/3/1604.jpg","creators_name":"The Centre for 21st Century Humanities in University of New Castle","creators_email":"Julie.McIntyre@newcastle.edu.au","creators_url":"","star_average":0.0,"url":"https://www.newcastle.edu.au/research-and-innovation/centre/education-arts/cllc/intelligent-archive","last_updated":"2020-02-07","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/3/1604-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: Intelligent Archive is a Java application for stylometry, or computational and statistical analysis of style in texts, produced by the University of Newcastle's Centre for Literary and Linguistic Computing (CLLC). It can handle corpora of plain text, HTML, XML and TEI texts. IA enables you to easily organise texts into sets, manage metadata, generate word frequencies, handle XML tags, and split texts in various ways to generate results that can be exported for further analysis in statistical software. It includes some experimental stylometry techniques developed at the CLLC and special features for handling literary texts such as generating word frequencies for speaking characters in plays.
name: Intelligent Archive

data_tapor: {"id":1606,"user_id":1201,"name":"gensim","detail":"Gensim is an open-source library for unsupervised topic modeling and natural language processing, using modern statistical machine learning.\nGensim is implemented in Python and Cython. Gensim is designed to handle large text collections using data streaming and incremental online algorithms, which differentiates it from most other machine learning software packages that target only in-memory processing. Gensim includes streamed parallelized implementations of fastText, word2vec and doc2vec algorithms, as well as latent semantic analysis (LSA, LSI, SVD), non-negative matrix factorization (NMF), latent Dirichlet allocation (LDA), tf-idf and random projections.","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/3/1606.jpg","creators_name":"Radim Řehůřek","creators_email":"me@radimrehurek.com","creators_url":"https://radimrehurek.com/","star_average":0.0,"url":"https://radimrehurek.com/gensim/","last_updated":"2020-02-07","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"https://github.com/piskvorky/gensim","thumb_url":"images/tools/3/1606-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail:
Gensim is an open-source library for unsupervised topic modeling and natural language processing, using modern statistical machine learning.
Gensim is implemented in Python and Cython. Gensim is designed to handle large text collections using data streaming and incremental online algorithms, which differentiates it from most other machine learning software packages that target only in-memory processing. Gensim includes streamed parallelized implementations of fastText, word2vec and doc2vec algorithms, as well as latent semantic analysis (LSA, LSI, SVD), non-negative matrix factorization (NMF), latent Dirichlet allocation (LDA), tf-idf and random projections.
name: Gensim

data_tapor: {"id":1612,"user_id":1201,"name":"Archivematica","detail":"Archivematica is a web- and standards-based, open-source application which allows your institution to preserve long-term access to trustworthy, authentic and reliable digital content.\nArchivematica is an integrated suite of open-source software tools that allows users to process digital objects from ingest to access in compliance with the ISO-OAIS functional model. Users monitor and control ingest and preservation micro-services via a web-based dashboard. Archivematica uses METS, PREMIS, Dublin Core, the Library of Congress BagIt specification and other recognized standards to generate trustworthy, authentic, reliable and system-independent Archival Information Packages (AIPs) for storage in your preferred repository.","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/3/1612.jpg","creators_name":"Artefactual","creators_email":"info@artefactual.com","creators_url":"http://www.artefactual.com","star_average":0.0,"url":"https://www.archivematica.org/en/","last_updated":"2020-02-17","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"https://github.com/artefactual","thumb_url":"images/tools/3/1612-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail:
Archivematica is a web- and standards-based, open-source application which allows your institution to preserve long-term access to trustworthy, authentic and reliable digital content.
Archivematica is an integrated suite of open-source software tools that allows users to process digital objects from ingest to access in compliance with the ISO-OAIS functional model. Users monitor and control ingest and preservation micro-services via a web-based dashboard. Archivematica uses METS, PREMIS, Dublin Core, the Library of Congress BagIt specification and other recognized standards to generate trustworthy, authentic, reliable and system-independent Archival Information Packages (AIPs) for storage in your preferred repository.
name: Archivematica

detail: MIX 2.0 is a sophisticated statistical add-in for performing meta-analysis in Excel. There is a free ‘Lite’ version and a premium ‘Pro’ version. Both can be downloaded for free, but the Pro version requires an activation with a license code that can be purchased. It works only on windows on Excel 2007 and later. Basic knowledge of Excel is required.
name: MIX 2.0

data_tapor: {"id":1618,"user_id":1201,"name":"Layar","detail":"The Layar Reality Browser is a free iPhone or Android augmented reality app that lets users look through their mobile device's camera to see “real time digital information (layers) on top of reality.” Some examples of layers are Architecture 3D, Foursquare, Google local search, Trulia, Twitter, Wikipedia and Yellowpages. The app itself is an augmented reality browser and users must download specific layers in order to view and access content. Most layers are free downloads, others cost around $2.00.\nIndividuals and businesses can use Layar to add links, videos, audio, etc to their flyers, logos or products. The product is scanned with a mobile phone camera through the Layar app.\nThe company seems to be bankrupted and Layar might not be in further development.","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/3/1618.jpg","creators_name":"Blippar Group","creators_email":"","creators_url":"","star_average":0.0,"url":"https://www.layar.com/","last_updated":"2020-02-17","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/3/1618-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail:
The Layar Reality Browser is a free iPhone or Android augmented reality app that lets users look through their mobile device's camera to see “real time digital information (layers) on top of reality.” Some examples of layers are Architecture 3D, Foursquare, Google local search, Trulia, Twitter, Wikipedia and Yellowpages. The app itself is an augmented reality browser and users must download specific layers in order to view and access content. Most layers are free downloads, others cost around $2.00.
Individuals and businesses can use Layar to add links, videos, audio, etc to their flyers, logos or products. The product is scanned with a mobile phone camera through the Layar app.
The company seems to be bankrupted and Layar might not be in further development.
name: Layar

detail:
Historypin is a digital, user-generated archive of historical photos, videos, audio recordings and personal recollections. Users are able to use the location and date of their content to "pin" it to Google Maps. Where Google Street View is available, users can overlay historical photographs and compare it with the contemporary location.

This content can be added and explored online and via a series of Smartphone applications
name: Historypin

data_tapor:
{"id":1634,"user_id":1201,"name":"Sketch Engine","detail":"Sketch Engine is a tool to explore how language works. Its algorithms analyze authentic texts of billions of words (text corpora) to identify instantly what is typical in language and what is rare, unusual or emerging usage. It is also designed for text analysis or text mining applications.

Sketch Engine is used by linguists, lexicographers, translators, students and teachers. It is a first choice solution for publishers, universities, translation agencies and national language institutes throughout the world.

Sketch Engine contains 500 ready-to-use corpora in 90+ languages, each having a size of up to 30 billion words to provide a truly representative sample of language.

Some of its functions are: word sketch, sketch difference, thesaurus, concordance, parallel concordance, wordlist, n-grams, keywords & terms, bilingual term extractiontrends and OneClick Dictionary.","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/3/1634.jpg","creators_name":"Lexical Computing","creators_email":"inquiries@lexicalcomputing.com","creators_url":"","star_average":0.0,"url":"https://www.sketchengine.eu/","last_updated":"2021-03-26","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/3/1634-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail:
Sketch Engine is a tool to explore how language works. Its algorithms analyze authentic texts of billions of words (text corpora) to identify instantly what is typical in language and what is rare, unusual or emerging usage. It is also designed for text analysis or text mining applications.

Sketch Engine is used by linguists, lexicographers, translators, students and teachers. It is a first choice solution for publishers, universities, translation agencies and national language institutes throughout the world.

Sketch Engine contains 500 ready-to-use corpora in 90+ languages, each having a size of up to 30 billion words to provide a truly representative sample of language.

Some of its functions are: word sketch, sketch difference, thesaurus, concordance, parallel concordance, wordlist, n-grams, keywords & terms, bilingual term extractiontrends and OneClick Dictionary.
name: Sketch Engine

{"id":1638,"user_id":1201,"name":"MassMine","detail":"MassMine is a command line tool designed for researchers to simplify the collection and use of data from online sources such as social media networks. Geared toward novices and power users alike.

Designed for use on personal computers or on headless servers.

Handles the acquisition of API data while managing rate limits imposed by these services.

Makes setting up custom data requests easy, allowing for flexible deployment for individualized research needs.

Creates and manages databases of collected data automatically. This means that all tweets, trends, posts, etc. related to your research questions are saved permanently on your local hard drive.

Designed for long-running data collection projects. MassMine makes it easy to create your own database of social media content spanning days, months, or years.","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/3/1638.jpg","creators_name":"Dr. Nicholas Van Horn","creators_email":"nvanhorn@protonmail.com","creators_url":"https://www.nicholasvanhorn.com/","star_average":0.0,"url":"https://www.massmine.org/index.html","last_updated":"2020-10-22","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"https://github.com/n3mo/","thumb_url":"images/tools/3/1638-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail:
MassMine is a command line tool designed for researchers to simplify the collection and use of data from online sources such as social media networks. Geared toward novices and power users alike.

Designed for use on personal computers or on headless servers.

Handles the acquisition of API data while managing rate limits imposed by these services.

Makes setting up custom data requests easy, allowing for flexible deployment for individualized research needs.

Creates and manages databases of collected data automatically. This means that all tweets, trends, posts, etc. related to your research questions are saved permanently on your local hard drive.

Designed for long-running data collection projects. MassMine makes it easy to create your own database of social media content spanning days, months, or years.
name: MassMine

data_tapor: {"id":1644,"user_id":1201,"name":"TextAnnotator","detail":"TextAnnotator is a web based annotation tool implemented with the JavaScript framework ExtJS and the visualization library d3.js  that can process and annotate NLP documents in UIMA (Unstructured Information Management applications) format. \nTextAnnotator is a framework that offers several annotation tools for generating IMA-compliant training data that can be used to train classifiers in support of the needs of humanities scholars.\nNote: The tool is currently not working.","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/3/1644.jpg","creators_name":"Text Technology Lab","creators_email":"","creators_url":"https://www.texttechnologylab.org/","star_average":0.0,"url":"http://www.textannotator.texttechnologylab.org/","last_updated":"2021-01-21","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/3/1644-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail:
TextAnnotator is a web based annotation tool implemented with the JavaScript framework ExtJS and the visualization library d3.js  that can process and annotate NLP documents in UIMA (Unstructured Information Management applications) format. 
TextAnnotator is a framework that offers several annotation tools for generating IMA-compliant training data that can be used to train classifiers in support of the needs of humanities scholars.
Note: The tool is currently not working.
name: TextAnnotator

detail:
VAnnotatoR is a system that massively supports the annotation of multimedia, multimodal networks of linguistic and object-related data in virtual 3D environments.

VAnnotatoR allows for segmenting and linking texts and images with other multimedia, multimodal data to ultimately create spatial hypertexts. It can be used to support concrete technical applications, e.g. the reconstruction of 3D scenes from texts as a preparatory step for the training of Text2Scene systems, or for applications in the digital humanities, such as the spatial reconstruction and linking of historical scenes or biographies with corresponding media content, such as images or 3D reconstructions of historical buildings. The entire system is interactively accessible with VR glasses in Virtual Reality (VR) and can be controlled and experienced accordingly. VAnnotatoR uses TextAnnotator as technological backbone and thus all its functions for annotation, task management, annotation evaluation as well as for collaborative and simultaneous processing of resources. Furthermore, VAnnotatoR uses TextImager to benefit from its NLP routines for automatic text analysis. VAnnotatoR is implemented on the basis of Unity3D and OpenVR and therefore runs with both systems and several VR glasses – it was tested on Oculus Rift, Oculus Rift S, Oculus Quest, HTC Vive and HTC Vive Cosmos under Windows 10.

A demonstration of its usage can be found here https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BBUg8mHT0iI
name: VAnnotatoR

data_tapor: {"id":1646,"user_id":1201,"name":"TreeTagger","detail":"The TreeTagger is a program developed by Helmut Schmid at the University of Stuttgart (now at the University of München), for part-of-speech tagging and lemmatization. Language models (known as “parameters”, file extension .par) are supplied on the TreeTagger webpage for using the program with texts in English, French, German, Italian, Spanish, Russian, Bulgarian, Dutch, Estonian, Finnish, Galician, Latin, Mongolian, Polish, Slovak and Swahili, and models for some other languages are available from sites linked to the TreeTagger webpage. For a language for which no model exists, it is necessary to hand-tag some text, and then run a training program (provided with the TreeTagger) to create the model.","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/3/1646.jpg","creators_name":"Helmut Schmid","creators_email":"LastName@cis.lmu.de","creators_url":"https://www.cis.uni-muenchen.de/~schmid/","star_average":0.0,"url":"https://www.cis.uni-muenchen.de/~schmid/tools/TreeTagger/","last_updated":"2021-01-21","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"http://www.smo.uhi.ac.uk/~oduibhin/oideasra/interfaces/winttinterface.htm","thumb_url":"images/tools/3/1646-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: The TreeTagger is a program developed by Helmut Schmid at the University of Stuttgart (now at the University of München), for part-of-speech tagging and lemmatization. Language models (known as “parameters”, file extension .par) are supplied on the TreeTagger webpage for using the program with texts in English, French, German, Italian, Spanish, Russian, Bulgarian, Dutch, Estonian, Finnish, Galician, Latin, Mongolian, Polish, Slovak and Swahili, and models for some other languages are available from sites linked to the TreeTagger webpage. For a language for which no model exists, it is necessary to hand-tag some text, and then run a training program (provided with the TreeTagger) to create the model.
name: TreeTagger

{"id":1668,"user_id":1201,"name":"Nocode app","detail":"

The Nocode app is a suite of data exploration tools (or functions) that can be used by analysts, students, researchers and journalist to analyse text. It currently has 5 functions:

Umigon: sentiment analysis for social media, in English and French.

Cowo: transform your texts into networks.

Topics: identify the key topics in texts of any language.

Gaze: find the network structure in your list of items.

Organic: distinguish natural from corporate tweets.

It is free to use. It can be used on a browser and the app can be downloaded and installed on a local computer.","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/3/1668.jpg","creators_name":"Clement Levallois","creators_email":"clementlevallois@protonmail.com","creators_url":"http://twitter.com/seinecle","star_average":0.0,"url":"https://seinecle.github.io/nocodeapp-mods/","last_updated":"2021-06-11","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"https://seinecle.github.io/nocodeapp-mods/","thumb_url":"images/tools/3/1668-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail:
The Nocode app is a suite of data exploration tools (or functions) that can be used by analysts, students, researchers and journalist to analyse text. It currently has 5 functions:
Umigon: sentiment analysis for social media, in English and French.
Cowo: transform your texts into networks. 
Topics: identify the key topics in texts of any language.
Gaze: find the network structure in your list of items.
Organic: distinguish natural from corporate tweets.

It is free to use. It can be used on a browser and the app can be downloaded and installed on a local computer.
name: Nocode app

It is made for researchers by researchers, no programming/API skills required. With Netlytic you can:
capture publicly available posts from social media sites or other sources (Twitter, YouTube, RSS Feed, or text/csv file)
Discover popular topics
Find and explore emerging themes of discussions
Build, visualize and analyze online communication networks using social network analysis
Map geo-coded social media data
","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/3/1671.jpg","creators_name":"Dr. Anatoliy Gruzd","creators_email":"netlytic@gmail.com","creators_url":"https://anatoliygruzd.com/","star_average":0.0,"url":"https://netlytic.org/","last_updated":"2021-07-16","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/3/1671-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail:
Netlytic is a community-supported text and social networks analyzer that can automatically summarize and visualize public online conversations on social media sites. It is made for researchers by researchers, no programming/API skills required.

With Netlytic you can: 

capture publicly available posts from social media sites or other sources (Twitter, YouTube, RSS Feed, or text/csv file)
Discover popular topics
Find and explore emerging themes of discussions
Build, visualize and analyze online communication networks using social network analysis
Map geo-coded social media data
name: Netlytic

data_tapor: {"id":1672,"user_id":1201,"name":"Communalytic","detail":"Communalytic is a research tool for studying online communities and online discourse.\nCommunalytic can collect and analyze public data from social media platforms. It uses advanced text and social network analysis techniques to automatically pinpoint toxic and anti-social interactions, identify influencers, map shared interests and the spread of misinformation, and detect signs of possible coordination among seemingly disparate actors.","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/3/1672.jpg","creators_name":"Anatoliy Gruzd","creators_email":"","creators_url":"https://anatoliygruzd.com/","star_average":0.0,"url":"https://communalytic.com/","last_updated":"2021-07-16","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/3/1672-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail:
Communalytic is a research tool for studying online communities and online discourse.
Communalytic can collect and analyze public data from social media platforms. It uses advanced text and social network analysis techniques to automatically pinpoint toxic and anti-social interactions, identify influencers, map shared interests and the spread of misinformation, and detect signs of possible coordination among seemingly disparate actors.
name: Communalytic

{"id":1673,"user_id":1201,"name":"Recoll","detail":"Recoll is used to search for documents based on their content as well as thier filenames.
Recoll can search documents on many different formats and from a variety of storages (files, archive members, email attachments, etc while transparently handling decompression.
It is free on Linux, open source, and licensed under the GPL.
It is based on the very capable Xapian search engine library, for which it provides a powerful text extraction layer and a complete, yet easy to use, Qt graphical interface.","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/3/1673.jpg","creators_name":"Jean-Francois Dockes","creators_email":"jfd@recoll.org","creators_url":"https://www.lesbonscomptes.com/","star_average":0.0,"url":"https://www.lesbonscomptes.com/recoll/","last_updated":"2021-08-13","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"https://framagit.org/medoc92/recoll","thumb_url":"images/tools/3/1673-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail:
Recoll is used to search for documents based on their content as well as thier filenames.
Recoll can search documents on many different formats and from a variety of storages (files, archive members, email attachments, etc while transparently handling decompression.
It is free on Linux, open source, and licensed under the GPL.
It is based on the very capable Xapian search engine library, for which it provides a powerful text extraction layer and a complete, yet easy to use, Qt graphical interface.
name: Recoll

detail: Sonic Visualiser is a free, open-source application for Windows, Linux, and Mac, designed to study a music recording closely. It's designed for musicologists, archivists, signal-processing researchers, and anyone else looking for a friendly way to look at what lies inside the audio file. Its latest release was September 2021. Its main functions are visualisation, analysis, and annotation of music audio recordings.
name: Sonic Visualiser

detail:
Odyssey.js is an open-source tool that allows you to combine maps, narratives, and other multimedia into a beautiful story. You enhance the narrative and multimedia of your stories using Actions (e.g. map movements, video and sound control, or the display or new content) that will let you tell your story in an exciting new way.

Experts can also add custom Templates and Actions by following the contribution guide. The tool is still under development and will include YouTube, Vimeo, Soundcloud, and Twitter based Actions.

The library is open source and freely available to use in your projects.
name: Odyssey

The users don't need to write code  but they can use variables, conditional logic, images, CSS, and JavaScript to enhance their stories if needed. The story is published in HTML and hence can be shared anywhere online.","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/3/1683.jpg","creators_name":"Chris Klimas","creators_email":"hello@chrisklimas.com","creators_url":"https://chrisklimas.com/","star_average":0.0,"url":"https://twinery.org/","last_updated":"2021-11-05","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"https://github.com/klembot/twinejs","thumb_url":"images/tools/3/1683-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail: Twine is an open-source tool for telling interactive, nonlinear stories. The users don't need to write code  but they can use variables, conditional logic, images, CSS, and JavaScript to enhance their stories if needed. The story is published in HTML and hence can be shared anywhere online.
name: Twine

data_tapor: {"id":1684,"user_id":1201,"name":"the sourcecaster","detail":"The sourcecaster helps users work in the windows command line. It contains short lines of code that can be used to manipulate files for analysis. File types include image, video, text, audio, etc. Below each line of code are explanations that tell what each part of the code does and so the user can modify the code to suite his/her objectives. The sourcecaster relies on contributions from the community. data_tapor:
{"id":1691,"user_id":1201,"name":"Archive Alert","detail":"

Archive Alert is an online platform that allows individuals, entities, groups, and organizations to report on archives and/or other cultural material which promotes cultural heritage (audiovisual material, maps, photographs, printed material, newspapers, posters, etc.). The users may report material they are in possession of, or material threatened by ignorance, negligence, or due to lack of expert human resources.

Registered users can report on their own historical documents either to inform archival organizations, or to invite specialized staff to archive, file, preserve and utilize the material. The platform allows for anonymous or eponymous/public registration, and then, depending on the material reported, it automatically informs all organizations/entities that may be concerned.

The platform is free for users-informants and archival organizations; any kind of buying and selling of archival and cultural material is strictly forbidden.

The homepage and introduction pages are in English while the archive report section is only available in Greek. There are currently only two reports of archives in the website.","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/3/1691.jpg","creators_name":"Arxeion Taxis","creators_email":"","creators_url":"https://arxeiontaxis.gr/en/homepage/","star_average":0.0,"url":"https://archivealert.gr/web/en/index","last_updated":"2022-02-08","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/3/1691-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail:
Archive Alert is an online platform that allows individuals, entities, groups, and organizations to report on archives and/or other cultural material which promotes cultural heritage (audiovisual material, maps, photographs, printed material, newspapers, posters, etc.). The users may report material they are in possession of, or material threatened by ignorance, negligence, or due to lack of expert human resources.
Registered users can report on their own historical documents either to inform archival organizations, or to invite specialized staff to archive, file, preserve and utilize the material. The platform allows for anonymous or eponymous/public registration, and then, depending on the material reported, it automatically informs all organizations/entities that may be concerned.
The platform is free for users-informants and archival organizations; any kind of buying and selling of archival and cultural material is strictly forbidden.
The homepage and introduction pages are in English while the archive report section is only available in Greek. There are currently only two reports of archives in the website.
name: Archive Alert

data_tapor: {"id":1692,"user_id":1364,"name":"Scalar","detail":"\u003cp\u003eScalar is a free, open source semantic web authoring and publishing tool. It helps long-form authors to produce born digital scholarship online. The tool offers a mixture of standardization and structural flexibility so as to provide the users with a platform where they can assemble media from multiple sources and link it to their writings in different ways. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e In addition to having a built-in reading interface, Scalar also has an API that permits custom-designed applications to use Scalar content. It encourages improvisation to the data model used by users, especially if the content they are dealing with is structured and small to moderate in size. The platform also supports collaborative authoring and reader commentary. \u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":false,"image_url":"images/tools/3/1692.jpg","creators_name":"Tara McPherson","creators_email":"","creators_url":"https://cinema.usc.edu/directories/profile.cfm?id=6590","star_average":0.0,"url":"https://scalar.me/anvc/scalar/","last_updated":"2022-02-17","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/3/1692-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail:
Scalar is a free, open source semantic web authoring and publishing tool. It helps long-form authors to produce born digital scholarship online. The tool offers a mixture of standardization and structural flexibility so as to provide the users with a platform where they can assemble media from multiple sources and link it to their writings in different ways. 
 In addition to having a built-in reading interface, Scalar also has an API that permits custom-designed applications to use Scalar content. It encourages improvisation to the data model used by users, especially if the content they are dealing with is structured and small to moderate in size. The platform also supports collaborative authoring and reader commentary.
name: Scalar

data_tapor: {"id":1698,"user_id":1364,"name":"Bichitra: Online Tagore Variorum","detail":"\u003cp\u003e Bichitra is the biggest integrated knowledge site devoted to any author in any language to date. It comprises most versions of nearly all Tagore’s works in Bengali and English. It excludes most letters, speeches, textbooks and translations, except Tagore’s translations from his own Bengali. It includes digital images of virtually all his manuscripts and authoritative print versions (books and journals), 47,520 pages of manuscripts and 91,637 pages of printed books and journals and plain-text transcripts of all these versions. It also acts as a search engine to locate words and phrases in Tagore's works and as a collation engine to compare different versions of a work at three levels: chapter (in a long prose work) or act/scene (in a play); paragraph (in prose) or stanza (in verse). It also has a checklist of the contents of each manuscript and a bibliography of all authoritative manuscript and print versions of each work. \u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":false,"image_url":"images/tools/3/1698.jpg","creators_name":"School of Cultural Texts and Records, Jadavpur University, Kolkata","creators_email":"bichitra.culture@school.jdvu.ac.in","creators_url":"http://bichitra.jdvu.ac.in/about_sctr.php","star_average":0.0,"url":"http://bichitra.jdvu.ac.in/index.php","last_updated":"2022-03-09","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/3/1698-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}

It includes digital images of virtually all his manuscripts and authoritative print versions (books and journals), 47,520 pages of manuscripts and 91,637 pages of printed books and journals and plain-text transcripts of all these versions. It also acts as a search engine to locate words and phrases in Tagore's works and as a collation engine to compare different versions of a work at three levels: chapter (in a long prose work) or act/scene (in a play); paragraph (in prose) or stanza (in verse). It also has a checklist of the contents of each manuscript and a bibliography of all authoritative manuscript and print versions of each work.

{"id":1700,"user_id":1201,"name":"TWINT - Twitter Intelligence Tool","detail":"Twint is an advanced Twitter scraping tool written in Python that allows for scraping Tweets from Twitter profiles without using Twitter's API. Twint utilizes Twitter's search operators to let you scrape Tweets from specific users, scrape Tweets relating to certain topics, hashtags & trends, or sort out sensitive information from Tweets like e-mail and phone numbers. I find this very useful, and you can get really creative with it too. Twint also makes special queries to Twitter allowing you to also scrape a Twitter user's followers, Tweets a user has liked, and who they follow without any authentication, API, Selenium, or browser emulation.
Recently it looks like Twitter has found a way to limit the number of tweets scraped using twint.
Twint also has a visualizer and a desktop app is under development.","is_approved":true,"image_url":"images/tools/3/1700.jpg","creators_name":"","creators_email":"","creators_url":"","star_average":0.0,"url":"https://github.com/twintproject/twint","last_updated":"2022-04-08","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"https://github.com/twintproject/twint","thumb_url":"images/tools/3/1700-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail:
Twint is an advanced Twitter scraping tool written in Python that allows for scraping Tweets from Twitter profiles without using Twitter's API.

Twint utilizes Twitter's search operators to let you scrape Tweets from specific users, scrape Tweets relating to certain topics, hashtags & trends, or sort out sensitive information from Tweets like e-mail and phone numbers. I find this very useful, and you can get really creative with it too.

Twint also makes special queries to Twitter allowing you to also scrape a Twitter user's followers, Tweets a user has liked, and who they follow without any authentication, API, Selenium, or browser emulation.
Recently it looks like Twitter has found a way to limit the number of tweets scraped using twint. Twint also has a visualizer and a desktop app is under development.
name: TWINT - Twitter Intelligence Tool

data_tapor: {"id":1702,"user_id":1364,"name":"Rekhta","detail":"\u003cp\u003eEstablished with the aim of disseminating and promoting Urdu literature, with a focus on poetry, Rekhta.org is a free website with archival material available in Roman and Devnagari script along with the Urdu script. The website has a large number of features that make it extremely user-friendly and provides the reader unparalleled convenience in the ability to browse, search and find relevant content with its customized powerful search facility. The website allows one to see the translation as well as transliteration of Urdu words to Hindi and English. It also has the unique feature of an in-built glossary that provides the meaning of every word at just a click. In order to give the uninitiated reader a flavour of the diction and pronunciation, a large number of compositions have been recorded in the voice of poets and professionals and have been provided along with the text. The website also has an Urdu dictionary. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt has started a section of Urdu Shayari for beginners wherein newcomers to the world of Urdu poetry are introduced to relatively easy poetry as well as popular Ghazals and Nazms along with videos of these compositions sung and recited by well known artists and poets. It has also started an initiative to digitize Urdu literature, both poetry and prose, in order to preserve rare and popular Urdu books.  Apart from sourcing books from personal collections of various people, it has also associated with reputed libraries and organizations to digitize their collections.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":false,"image_url":"images/tools/3/1702.jpg","creators_name":"Sanjiv Saraf","creators_email":"","creators_url":"","star_average":0.0,"url":"https://www.rekhta.org/","last_updated":"2022-05-06","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/3/1702-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail:
Established with the aim of disseminating and promoting Urdu literature, with a focus on poetry, Rekhta.org is a free website with archival material available in Roman and Devnagari script along with the Urdu script. The website has a large number of features that make it extremely user-friendly and provides the reader unparalleled convenience in the ability to browse, search and find relevant content with its customized powerful search facility. The website allows one to see the translation as well as transliteration of Urdu words to Hindi and English. It also has the unique feature of an in-built glossary that provides the meaning of every word at just a click. In order to give the uninitiated reader a flavour of the diction and pronunciation, a large number of compositions have been recorded in the voice of poets and professionals and have been provided along with the text. The website also has an Urdu dictionary. 
It has started a section of Urdu Shayari for beginners wherein newcomers to the world of Urdu poetry are introduced to relatively easy poetry as well as popular Ghazals and Nazms along with videos of these compositions sung and recited by well known artists and poets. It has also started an initiative to digitize Urdu literature, both poetry and prose, in order to preserve rare and popular Urdu books.  Apart from sourcing books from personal collections of various people, it has also associated with reputed libraries and organizations to digitize their collections.
name: Rekhta

data_tapor: {"id":1703,"user_id":1364,"name":"Rekhta Dictionary","detail":"\u003cp\u003eRekhta Dictionary is a new initiative of Rekhta Foundation for the promotion and preservation of Urdu language and literature. Since 2011, the Foundation has been running multiple websites including Rekhta, Sufinama, Hindwi, and Aamozish.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe Rekhta Dictionary is a comprehensive collection of Urdu words with their meanings in Urdu, Hindi and English. The words can easily be accessed in three scripts through a high-functioning search engine. Along with detailed meanings, it gives the list of synonyms, antonyms, proverbs, idioms and much more.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis trilingual Urdu dictionary is designed as a resourceful tool for the researchers, poetry-lovers, and general readers irrespective of their familiarity with Urdu script.\u003c/p\u003e","is_approved":false,"image_url":"images/tools/3/1703.jpg","creators_name":"Sanjiv Saraf","creators_email":"","creators_url":"","star_average":0.0,"url":"https://rekhtadictionary.com/","last_updated":"2022-05-06","nature":"tool","language":null,"code":null,"repository":"","thumb_url":"images/tools/3/1703-thumb.jpg","rating_count":0,"recipes":""}
detail:
Rekhta Dictionary is a new initiative of Rekhta Foundation for the promotion and preservation of Urdu language and literature. Since 2011, the Foundation has been running multiple websites including Rekhta, Sufinama, Hindwi, and Aamozish.
The Rekhta Dictionary is a comprehensive collection of Urdu words with their meanings in Urdu, Hindi and English. The words can easily be accessed in three scripts through a high-functioning search engine. Along with detailed meanings, it gives the list of synonyms, antonyms, proverbs, idioms and much more.
This trilingual Urdu dictionary is designed as a resourceful tool for the researchers, poetry-lovers, and general readers irrespective of their familiarity with Urdu script.
name: Rekhta Dictionary
